ARTICLE I
Adoption of Code
[Adopted 10-10-2011 by Ord. No. 432]
§ 1-1. Approval, adoption and enactment of Code.
Pursuant to Section 1008(b) of the Borough Code (53 P.S. §46008(b)), the codification of a complete
body of legislation for the Borough of Birdsboro, County of Berks, Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, as
revised, codified and consolidated into chapters, articles and sections by General Code, and consisting
of Chapters 1 through 395, together with an Appendix, are hereby approved, adopted, ordained and
enacted as a single ordinance of the Borough of Birdsboro, which shall be known and is hereby designated
as the "Code of the Borough of Birdsboro," hereinafter referred to as the "Code."
§ 1-2. Effect of Code on previous provisions.
The provisions of this Code, insofar as they are substantively the same as those of ordinances and resolutions
in force immediately prior to the enactment of the ordinance codified in this article, are intended
as a continuation of such ordinances and resolutions and not as new enactments, and the effectiveness
of such provisions shall date from the date of adoption of the prior ordinance or resolution. All such pro§
1-3 BIRDSBORO CODE § 1-4
01-04-2016 1:2
visions are hereby continued in full force and effect and are hereby reaffirmed as to their adoption by
the Borough Council of the Borough of Birdsboro, and it is the intention of said Borough Council that
each such provision contained within the Code is hereby reenacted and reaffirmed as it appears in said
Code. Only such provisions of former ordinance as are omitted from this Code shall be deemed
repealed or abrogated by the provisions of § 1-3, and only changed provisions, as described in § 1-6,
shall be deemed to be enacted from the effective date of this Code, as provided in § 1-15.
§ 1-3. Repeal of ordinances not contained in Code.
All ordinances or parts of ordinances of a general and permanent nature adopted by the Borough of
Birdsboro and in force on the date of the adoption of this Code and not contained in the Code are hereby
repealed as of the effective date given in § 1-15, except as hereinafter provided.
§ 1-4. Ordinances saved from repeal; matters not affected by repeal.
The adoption of this Code and the repeal of ordinances provided for in § 1-13 shall not affect the following
ordinances, rights and obligations, which are hereby expressly saved from repeal; provided,
however, that the repeal of ordinances pursuant to § 1-3 or the saving from repeal of ordinances pursuant
to this section shall not be construed so as to revive any ordinance previously repealed, superseded
or no longer of any effect:
A. Any ordinance adopted subsequent to April 12, 2011.
B. Any right or liability established, accrued or incurred under any legislative provision of the Borough
prior to the effective date of the ordinance codified in this article or any action or proceeding
brought for the enforcement of such right or liability or any cause of action acquired or
existing.
C. Any offense or act committed or done before the effective date of the ordinance codified in this
article in violation of any legislative provision of the Borough or any penalty, punishment or forfeiture
which may result therefrom.
D. Any prosecution, indictment, action, suit or other proceeding pending or any judgment rendered
prior to the effective date of the ordinance codified in this article, brought pursuant to any legislative
provisions of the Borough.
E. Any franchise, license, right, easement or privilege theretofore granted or conferred by the Borough
or any lawful contract, obligation or agreement.
F. Any ordinance appropriating money or transferring funds, promising or guaranteeing the payment
of money or authorizing the issuance and delivery of any bond of the Borough or other
instruments or evidence of the Borough's indebtedness.
G. Any ordinance adopting an annual budget or establishing an annual tax rate.
H. Any ordinance providing for the levy, imposition or collection of special taxes, assessments or
charges.
I. Any ordinance authorizing the purchase, sale, lease or transfer of property or acquiring property
by acceptance of deed, condemnation or exercise of eminent domain.
§ 1-5 GENERAL PROVISIONS § 1-6
1:3 01-04-2016
J. Any ordinance annexing land to the Borough.
K. Any ordinance providing for or requiring the construction or reconstruction or opening of sidewalks,
curbs and gutters.
L. Any ordinance or part of an ordinance providing for laying out, opening, altering, widening, relocating,
straightening, establishing grade, changing name, improvement, acceptance or vacation
of any right-of-way, easement, street, road, highway, sidewalk, park or other public place or property
or designating various streets as public highway.
M. Any ordinance establishing water, sewer or other special purpose districts and designating the
boundaries thereof; providing for a system of sewers or water supply lines; or providing for the
construction, extension, dedication, acceptance or abandonment of any part of a system of sewers
or water supply lines.
N. Any ordinance providing for the making of public improvements.
O. Any ordinance providing for the salaries and compensation of officers and employees of the Borough
or setting the bond of any officer or employee.
P. Any ordinance concerning changes and amendments to the zoning map.
Q. Any ordinance relating to or establishing a pension plan or pension fund for municipal employees.
R. Any ordinance or portion of an ordinance establishing a specific fee amount for any license, permit
or service obtained from the Borough.
§ 1-5. Inclusion of new legislation prior to adoption of Code.
All ordinances of a general and permanent nature adopted subsequent to the date given in § 1-4A and/or
prior to the date of adoption of the ordinance codified in this article are hereby deemed to be a part of
the Code and shall, upon being printed, be included therein. Attested copies of all such ordinances shall
be temporarily placed in the Code until printed supplements are included.
§ 1-6. Changes and revisions in previously adopted ordinances.
A. Nonsubstantive grammatical changes. In compiling and preparing the ordinances and resolutions
of the Borough for adoption and revision as part of the Code, certain nonsubstantive grammatical
and style changes were made in one or more of said ordinances. It is the intention of the Borough
Council that all such changes be adopted as part of the Code as if the ordinances and resolutions
so changed had been previously formally amended to read as such.
B. Substantive changes and revisions. In addition to the changes and revisions described above,
changes and revisions of a substantive nature, as set forth in Schedule A attached hereto and
made a part hereof, are hereby made to various ordinances and resolutions included in the Code.
These changes are enacted to bring provisions into conformity with the desired policies of the
Borough Council, and it is the intent of the Borough Council that all such changes be adopted as
part of the Code as if the ordinances and resolutions so changed had been previously formally
§ 1-7 BIRDSBORO CODE § 1-10
01-04-2016 1:4
amended to read as such. All such changes and revisions shall be deemed to be in effect as of the
effective date of the Code specified in § 1-15.
C. Nomenclature. Throughout the Code the following terms are updated as indicated:
(1) "District Justice" is changed to "Magisterial District Justice."
(2) "Department of Environmental Resources" is changed to "Department of Environmental
Protection."
(3) "Department of Community Affairs" is changed to "Department of Community and Economic
Development."
§ 1-7. Interpretation of provisions.
In interpreting and applying the provisions of the Code, they shall be held to be the minimum requirements
for the promotion of the public health, safety, comfort, convenience and general welfare. Where
the provisions of the Code impose greater restrictions or requirements than those of any statute, other
ordinance, resolution or regulation, the provisions of the Code shall control. Where the provisions of
any statute, other ordinance, resolution or regulation impose greater restrictions or requirements, the
provisions of such statute, other ordinance, resolution or regulation shall control.
§ 1-8. Titles and headings; editor's notes.
A. Chapter and article titles, headings and titles of sections and other divisions in the Code or in supplements
made to the Code are inserted in the Code and may be inserted in supplements to the
Code for the convenience of persons using the Code and are not part of the legislation.
B. Editor's notes indicating sources of sections, giving other information or referring to the statutes
or to other parts of the Code are inserted in the Code and may be inserted in supplements to the
Code for the convenience of persons using the Code and are not part of legislation.
§ 1-9. Filing of copy of Code.
At least one copy of the Code in a post-bound volume shall be filed with the Ordinance Book in the
office of the Borough Secretary and shall remain there for use and examination by the public. Upon
adoption, such copy or copies shall be certified by the Borough Secretary, as provided by law, and such
certified copy or copies shall remain on file in the office of the Borough Secretary, available to persons
desiring to examine the same during all times while said Code is in effect.
§ 1-10. Amendments to Code.
Any and all additions, deletions, amendments or supplements to the Code, when passed and adopted in
such form as to indicate the intention of the Borough Council to be a part thereof, shall be deemed to be
incorporated into such Code so that reference to the Code shall be understood and intended to include
such changes. Whenever such additions, deletions, amendments or supplements to the Code shall be
§ 1-11 GENERAL PROVISIONS § 1-15
1:5 01-04-2016
adopted, they shall thereafter be printed and, as provided hereunder, inserted in the post-bound book
containing said Code as amendments and supplements thereto.
§ 1-11. Code books to be kept up-to-date.
It shall be the duty of the Borough Secretary or someone authorized and directed by him or her to keep
up-to-date the certified copy or copies of the book containing the Code required to be filed in the office
of the Borough Secretary for the use of the public. All changes in said Code and all ordinances and resolutions
adopted by the Borough Council subsequent to the effective date of this codification which the
Borough Council shall adopt specifically as part of the Code shall, when finally adopted, be included
therein by reference until such changes or new ordinances or resolutions are printed as supplements to
said Code books, at which time such supplements shall be inserted therein.
§ 1-12. Publication of notices.
The Borough Secretary, pursuant to law, shall cause to be published in the manner required a notice of
the introduction and of the adoption of the Code in a newspaper of general circulation in the Borough.
The enactment and application of this article, coupled with the publication of the notices of introduction
and adoption, as required by law, and the availability of a copy or copies of the Code for inspection by
the public, shall be deemed, held and considered to be due and legal publication of all provisions of the
Code for all purposes.
§ 1-13. Altering or tampering with Code; penalties for violation.
It shall be unlawful for anyone to improperly change or amend, by additions or deletions, or to alter or
tamper with the Code or any part or portion thereof, in any manner whatsoever, which will cause the
law of the Borough to be misrepresented thereby. Anyone violating this section of this article shall,
upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine not exceeding $600, plus costs of prosecution, and, in
default of payment thereof, by imprisonment for a term not exceeding 30 days.
§ 1-14. Severability.
The provisions of this article and of the Code adopted hereby are severable, and if any clause, sentence,
subsection, section, article, chapter or part thereof shall be adjudged by any court of competent jurisdiction
to be illegal, invalid or unconstitutional, such judgment or decision shall not affect, impair or invalidate
the remainder thereof but shall be confined in its operation and application to the clause, sentence,
subsection, section, article, chapter or part thereof rendered illegal, invalid or unconstitutional. It is
hereby declared to be the intent of the Borough Council that this article and the Code would have been
adopted if such illegal, invalid or unconstitutional clause, sentence, subsection, section, article, chapter
or part thereof had not been included therein.
§ 1-15. Effective date.
All provisions of this article and of the Code shall be in force and effect on and after October 10, 2011.

under provisions of the Municipality Authorities Act, 53 Pa.C.S.A. § 5601 et seq., as amended
and supplemented (the "Authorities Act"), for the purpose of exercising any and all powers
conferred by the Authorities Act.

Chapter 13
FIRE COMPANY
§ 13-1. Designation.
§ 13-2. Authorized activities.
§ 13-3. Additional authorized activities.
§ 13-4. Local governmental agency
immunity.
§ 13-5. Declaration.
[HISTORY: Adopted by the Borough Council of the Borough of Birdsboro 1-3-2011 by
Ord. No. 423. Amendments noted where applicable.]
§ 13-1. Designation.
The Borough of Birdsboro does hereby recognize and designate the Birdsboro-Union Fire
Department of the Borough of Birdsboro and the Township of Union, Berks County,
Pennsylvania as the official Fire Company to provide fire protection and related services to
the Borough of Birdsboro, its residences, businesses and related areas.
§ 13-2. Authorized activities.
A. The Borough recognizes, designates and authorizes all activities of the Birdsboro-Union
Fire Department normally related to the extinguishment and prevention of loss of life and
property from fire, automobile accidents, medical emergencies, hazardous materials
incidents, natural disasters and other dangerous situations.
B. In addition thereto, the Borough does hereby authorize such nonemergency and public
service functions as public safety education programs, firesafety education programs,
rescue education programs and other related activities all when authorized by the
appropriate officers of the Birdsboro-Union Fire Department of the Borough of Birdsboro
and Township of Union, Berks County, Pennsylvania.
§ 13-3. Additional authorized activities.
A. When authorized by an appropriate officer of the Birdsboro-Union Fire Department, the
Borough further recognizes and authorizes the Birdsboro-Union Fire Department to train
both inside and outside of the Borough of Birdsboro, to perform drills and practice runs
in the same manner, and to respond to and provide services to neighboring and
cooperating municipalities outside of the Borough, all in conjunction with appropriate
regional and fire-fighting activities.
B. Further, upon authorization of an appropriate officer of the Birdsboro-Union Fire
Department, the said Fire Company is hereby recognized as the official Fire Company of
the Borough of Birdsboro for participation and ceremonial events, including but not
limited parades, fund-raising activities, dedications and all such other similar activities as
authorized by the appropriate officer of the Birdsboro-Union Fire Department.
13:1 07 - 01 - 2011
§ 13-4 BIRDSBORO CODE § 13-5
§ 13-4. Local governmental agency immunity.
All such authorized activities of the authorized members of the Birdsboro-Union Fire
Department are hereby deemed to be subject to and construed under 42 Pa.C.S.A. § 8541,
regarding and concerning local governmental agency immunity.
§ 13-5. Declaration.
It is declared that the enactment of this chapter is necessary for the protection, benefit and
preservation of the health, safety and welfare of the inhabitants of the Borough, and that the
Birdsboro-Union Fire Department of the Borough of Birdsboro and Township of Union, Berks
County, Pennsylvania is and shall be the official Municipal Fire Department servicing the
municipality until further resolution, ordinance or other official act of this municipality.

Ord. No. 208. Amendments noted where applicable.]
§ 19-1. Establishment of Board. [Amended 4-12-2004 by Ord. No. 382]
The Board of Health is hereby established in and for the Borough of Birdsboro, in accordance
with the provisions of Article 31 of the Borough Code as amended by the Act of 1966,
February 1, P.L. (1965) 1656, No. 581. 1 The Board of Health shall have the general
supervision over sanitary conditions in the Borough and shall perform all the duties and may
exercise all the power vested by laws in boards of health in boroughs. The Board shall have
the power to perform such inspection as called for hereunder and to charge the sum of $50 for
such inspection. The said charge shall cover a single inspection and any additional inspection
which may be occasioned by a failure to comply, for a failure to pass the initial inspection or
any inspection shall thereafter shall be charged an additional fifty-dollar fee.
§ 19-2. Members.
The Board of Health shall be composed of five members, at least one of whom shall be a
physician of not less than two years experience in the practice of his profession. Members of
the Board shall be appointed by Borough Council. At the first appointment one member shall
be appointed to serve for one year, one for two years, one for three years, one for four years
and one for five years, and thereafter one member shall in like manner be appointed each year
to serve for five years. Members of the Board of Health shall serve without compensation.
§ 19-3. Secretary.
The Board of Health shall elect a Secretary, who need not be a member of the Board, who
shall keep the minutes of the proceedings of the Board; shall keep accurate accounts of the
expenditures of the Board; shall draw all requisitions for the payment of monies on account of
the Board of Health from appropriations made by the Council of the Board and shall present
the same to the President of the Board for his approval; shall render statements of the
expenditures to the Board at each stated meeting or as frequently as the Board may require;
shall prepare, under the directions of the Board, the annual reports to the Borough Council
1. Editor's Note: See 53 P.S. § 48101 et seq.
19: I 07 - 01 - 2011
§ 19-3 BIRDSBORO CODE § 19-8
together with the estimate of appropriation needed for the ensuing year. Further, he shall
report to the State Department of Health, at such intervals as shall be specified by the state
law or regulation, the cases of communicable disease reported to the Board of Health on the
form provided for that purpose by the Department; and shall make an annual report to such
Department and shall make such other reports and perform such other duties as the Board
may require. The Secretary of the Board of Health shall serve for a four-year term.
§ 19-4. Health Officer.
The Board of Health shall elect a Health Officer, who need not be a member of the Board, to
attend all stated and special meetings of the Board, and at all times be ready and available for
prompt performance of his official duties. He shall perform such duties as are vested in local
health officers by state laws and regulations. He shall make sanitary inspection and shall
execute the orders of the Board of Health and shall, in the performance of such duties, have
the power and authority of a policeman. The Health Officer shall serve a four-year term.
§ 19-5. Written report.
It shall be the duty of the Health Officer and the Secretary, upon request of Council, to submit
a joint written report to Council at its pre-Council session prior to the monthly meeting of
Council concerning the various problems and/or investigations made by the Board acting by
and through its Health Officer.
§ 19-6. Appointment of Board members.
It shall be the duty of the Borough Council to maintain the Board of Health at full
membership by appointment of new members as necessary to fill vacancies caused by
expiration of terms, death, removal from the Borough or other cause.
§ 19-7. Meetings.
The Board of Health shall meet at a stated time and place at least quarterly and shall hold
such other special meetings as the health conditions of the Borough may require. The said
Board shall hold its annual organization meeting in the month of February, at which time
officers for the ensuing year as prescribed by law shall be elected.
§ 19-8. Attendance of members.
If any member of the Board of Health, without sufficient cause, or without having been
excused from attendance thereat by the Board of Health, shall fail to attend the stated
meetings of the Board of Health or shall otherwise neglect his duties as a member of said
Board for a period of three consecutive meetings, he shall be considered to have withdrawn
from the membership of the Board of Health, and the Borough shall proceed to fill the
vacancy thus created.

§ 32-1. Creation of office.
GENERAL REFERENCES
Salaries and compensation - See Ch. 63.
ARTICLE I
Borough Manager
[Adopted 6-28-1962 by Ord. No. 130)
The Office of Borough Manager is hereby created by the Borough of Birdsboro, subject to the
right of the Borough, by ordinance, at any time to abolish such office.
§ 32-2. Filling of office. [Amended 2-10-2003 by Ord. No. 377)
The Borough Council shall select a Manager and by a majority vote of its members shall
appoint such person to fill the Office of Borough Manager who shall serve at the will of
Council. The Borough Manager shall be subject to removal at any time by a majority vote of
all of the members of Council. In the event the Borough Manager shall be afforded a contract
of employment by the Borough Council of the Borough of Birdsboro, such contract, where
not inconsistent with this article, shall prevail.
32:1 07 - 01 - 2011
§ 32-3 BIRDSBORO CODE § 32-7
§ 32-3. Qualifications. [Amended 2-10-2003 by Ord. No. 377]
The Manager shall be chosen solely on the basis of his/her executive and administrative
abilities with special reference to actual experience in or his or her knowledge of accepted
practices with respect to the duties of the office as herein outlined. Borough Council shall
require the Borough Manager to reside within a ten-mile radius of the Borough Hall of the
Borough of Birdsboro within a reasonable time after hiring.
§ 32-4. Bond. [Amended 3-13-2000 by Ord. No. 362]
Before entering upon his duties, the Borough Manager shall give a bond to the Borough, with
a bonding company as surety in such sum as shall be approved by Borough Council and as
shall be sufficient to bond the said Borough Manager for the performance of his normal
duties, the premium of said bond to be paid for by the Borough of Birdsboro. The bond of the
Borough Manager may be included in and the Manager may be bonded under and covered by
the blanket bond in force and effect for all Borough employees in an amount as fixed by
resolution of Borough Council and sufficient to cover all anticipated liabilities normally
covered by such bond.
§ 32-5. Compensation. [Amended 3-13-2000 by Ord. No. 362; 2-10-2003 by Ord. No.
377]
The Borough Manager shall receive such compensation, benefits or retirement benefits as
shall be fixed by Borough Council, from time to time, by resolution.
§ 32-6. Responsibilities.
The Manager shall be the chief administrative officer of the Borough, and he shall be
responsible to the Council as a whole for the proper and efficient administration of the affairs
of the Borough. His powers and duties shall relate to the general management of all Borough
business not expressly, by statute or ordinance, imposed or conferred upon other Borough
officers. The Mayor is hereby authorized to delegate to the Borough Manager, subject to
recall by written notification at any time, any of his nonlegislative and nonjudicial powers and
duties.
§ 32-7. Powers and duties.
A. Subject to recall by ordinance, the powers and duties of the Manager shall include the
following:
(1) He shall supervise and be responsible for the activities of all municipal
departments, except such departments the supervision of which shall not have been
delegated to the Manager by the Mayor or by Council, as the case may be.
(2) He shall hire and, when he shall deem it necessary for the good of the service,
shall suspend or discharge all employees under his supervision, provided that
persons covered by the civil service provisions of the Borough Code shall be hired,
suspended or discharged in accordance with such provisions. Provided further, that
32:2 07 - 01 - 2011
§ 32-7 OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES § 32-7
the Manager shall report, at the next regular meeting thereafter of Council, any
action taken by authority of this subsection.
(3) He shall prepare and submit to Council before the close of the fiscal year, or on
such alternate date as Council shall determine, a budget for the next fiscal year and
an explanatory budget message. In preparing the budget the Manager, or an officer
designated by him, shall obtain from the head of each department, agency, board
or officer estimates of revenues and expenditures and other supporting data as he
requests. The Manager shall review such estimates and may revise them before
submitting the budget to the Council.
(4) He shall be responsible for the administration of the budget after its adoption by
the Council.
(5) He shall, under the direction of the Mayor, execute and enforce the laws of the
Commonwealth, and ordinances, resolutions and bylaws of the Borough.
(6) In addition to the specific duties assigned to the Manager by this article, he shall
hold such offices as shall be assigned by Borough Council from time to time. 1
(7) He shall attend all meetings of the Borough Council and of its committees, with
the right to take part in the discussion, and he shall receive notice of all special
meetings of Council and of its committees.
(8) He shall prepare the agenda for each meeting of Council and supply facts pertinent
thereto .
(9) He shall keep the Council informed as to the conduct of Borough affairs; submit
periodic reports on the condition of the Borough finances and such other reports as
the Council shall request; and shall make such recommendations to the Council as
he deems necessary.
(I 0) He shall submit to Council, as soon as possible after the close of the fiscal year, a
complete report on the financial and administrative activities of the Borough for
the preceding year.
(11) He shall see that the provisions of all franchises, leases, permits and privileges
granted by the Borough are observed.
(12) He may employ, by and with the approval of Council, experts and consultants to
perform work and to advise in connection with any of the functions of the
Borough.
(13) He shall attend to the letting of contracts in due form of law, and he shall
supervise the performance and faithful execution of the same except insofar as
such duties are expressly imposed upon some other Borough officer by statute.
(14) He shall see that all money owed the Borough is promptly paid and that proper
proceedings are taken for the security and collection of all the Borough's claims.

§ 32-7 BIRDSBORO CODE § 32-11
(15) He shall be the purchasing officer of the Borough and he shall purchase, in
accordance with the provisions of the Borough Code, all supplies and equipment
for the various agencies, boards, departments and other offices of the Borough. He

§ 32-8. Substitution in absence.
In case of illness or absence of the Manager from the Borough, he shall delegate one qualified
member of his staff who shall perform the duties of the Manager during his absence or
disability. The person so designated shall not perform such duties for a period longer than two
weeks without the approval of the Council.
§ 32-9. Gender reference. [Added 2-10-2003 by Ord. No. 377)
All gender references herein shall include the masculine, as well as the feminine as if fully
specified therein.
ARTICLE II
Independent Auditor
[Adopted 12-2-1963 by Ord. No. 143)
§ 32-10. Creation of office.
The Office of appointed Borough Auditor is hereby created by the Borough of Birdsboro,
subject to the right of the Borough, by ordinance, at any time to abolish such office.
§ 32-11. Appointment of accountants.
As soon as practicable after the enactment of this article, the Borough Council shall appoint
annually, by resolution, before the commencement of the ensuing fiscal year, a certified public
accountant, a firm of certified public accountants, a competent independent public accountant
or a firm of independent public accountants to audit the accounts and other evidences of
financial transactions of the Borough and Borough officers for the fiscal year then closing,
and shall submit such audit report to Borough Council. The appointed Borough Auditor shall
be chosen solely on the basis of his or its accounting and bookkeeping abilities and need not
be a resident of the Borough.
32:4 07 - 01 - 2011
§ 32-12 OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES § 32-14
§ 32-12. Compensation.
The appointed Borough Auditor shall receive such compensation as shall be fixed in the
resolution appointing said auditor, and shall be paid out of Borough funds.
§ 32-13. Powers and duties.
The appointed Borough Auditor shall have the same powers and duties, and be subject to the
same penalties, as if the elected Borough Auditors were performing the audit of the accounts
and other evidences of financial transactions of the Borough and Borough officers.
§ 32-14. Abolishment of office of elected Borough Auditor.
The office of elected Borough Auditor is hereby abolished; provided, however, the elected
Borough Auditors now in office shall continue to hold their office during the term in which
elected, but shall not audit, settle or adjust the accounts to be audited by the appointed
Borough Auditor, but shall perform the duties of their office .

ARTICLE I
Nonuniformed Employees
[Adopted 12-28-1995 by Ord. No. 353]
Effective December 28, 1995, the Borough of Birdsboro as employer adopted the amended
and restated Borough of Birdsboro Nonuniformed Employees Pension Plan and executed a
trust agreement to provide retirement benefits for its employees. The plan and trust are
intended to meet the requirements of§§ 40l(a) and 501(a) of the Internal Revenue Code of
1986. The provisions of this amended and restated plan shall apply only to an employee who
terminates employment on or after the effective date of the amended and restated plan.

§ 38-2 BIRDSBORO CODE § 38-2
§ 38-2. Definitions.
A. The following terms have the meanings set forth below, unless a different meaning is
plainly required by the context:
ACTUARY - The enrolled actuary (within the meaning of the Act) engaged by the
Retirement Board.
ANNUITY STARTING DATE - The first day of the first period during which an
amount is payable as an annuity pursuant to the terms of the plan by reason of a
participant's retirement, permanent and total disability or termination of service for any
other reason except death.
AVERAGE MONTHLY COMPENSATION - Compensation averaged on a monthly
basis over the highest 36 consecutive months during the 84 months of credited service
immediately preceding the date of determination. [Amended 4-10-2000 by Ord. No.
364]
BOARD - The present or any succeeding Retirement Board.
CODE - The Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as now in effect or as hereafter
amended. All citations to sections of the code are to such sections as they may from time
to time be amended or renumbered.
COMPENSATION- All W-2 wages.
CREDITED SERVICE - Service which is credited for purposes of eligibility, vesting
and/or benefit accrual.
DATE OF DETERMINATION - The date as of which either the monthly amount or
the equivalent actuarial value of a participant's accrued benefits is determined pursuant to
the terms of the plan.
EFFECTIVE DATE OF THE PLAN - January 1, 1981.
EMPLOYEE - All individuals in the employ of the employer on a nonuniforrned
full-time basis.
EMPLOYER - Borough of Birdsboro.
EQUIVALENT ACTUARIAL VALUE - Equivalent value when computed on the
basis of the following actuarial tables:
(1) MORTALITY - UP-1984.
(2) INTEREST - Six percent.
FISCAL YEAR OF TRUST
December 31 of each year.
The accounting period for the trust which ends

§ 38-2 PENSIONS § 38-4

benefit plan as described herein or as hereinafter amended.
PLAN YEAR - The fiscal year of the trust.

§ 38-3. Misstatements and adjustments.
A. If it is found that the amount of monthly benefit provided under the plan with respect to
a participant is incorrect because of a misstatement as to his or her age, sex, length of
service, earnings or any other relevant fact, the amount of the monthly benefit shall be
equitably adjusted on the basis of the correct facts with respect to such participant,
subject to the sufficiency of the trust fund of the plan; provided, however, that if such
correct facts are brought to the attention of the Retirement Board after discontinuance or
termination of the plan, the amount of the monthly benefit will be adjusted to the amount
which could have been provided on the basis of the correct facts by the amount allocated
from the trust fund of the plan to provide such monthly benefit.
B. If it is ascertained that an overpayment has been made, the amount of such overpayment
will be charged against any further payments to the participant. If it is ascertained that an
underpayment has been made by the plan, the amount of such underpayment shall be
paid by the plan to the participant or person entitled thereto, subject to the sufficiency of
the trust fund of the plan.
§ 38-4. Administration.
In connection with the administration of the plan, the practice of the employer and the
Retirement Board, whenever there is a choice or decision to be made with respect to
participants of the plan, shall be uniformly applied to all similar circumstances, with the result
that there shall be no discrimination in the operation of the plan.
38:3 07 - 01 - 2011
§ 38-5 BIRDSBORO CODE § 38-8
§ 38-5. Construal of plan.
The plan shall be construed, regulated and administered under the laws of the Commonwealth
of Pennsylvania.
§ 38-6. Eligibility for membership.
A. An employee included as a participant under the prior provisions of the plan as of the
effective date of the restated plan shall continue to participate in accordance with the
provisions of this plan.
B. Commencing on the effective date of the restated plan, an employee, upon attainment of
age 21 and the completion of one year of service, shall enter the plan on the following:
(1) The first day of the plan year if hired prior to July 1, 1987.
(2) The first day of any calendar month if hired on or after July 1, 1987.
§ 38-7. Credited service.
A. Service credited for eligibility, vesting and benefit accrual. Subject to § 38-6B, all
periods of service completed by an employee (whether or not consecutive) shall be
aggregated in determining his service for purposes of eligibility, vesting and benefit
accrual. Service shall be aggregated on the basis that 12 months of service or 365 days of
service equal a year of credited service, and 30 days are deemed to be a month in the
case of aggregation of fractional months.
B. If a participant receives any benefit payments under the plan pursuant to § 38-8F(l) and
(2), the benefits payable upon his subsequent retirement shall be reduced by the
equivalent actuarial value of any benefit payments he received prior to his return to
service.
§ 38-8. Benefits. [Amended 4-10-2000 by Ord. No. 364]
A. Normal retirement date and benefit.
( 1) The normal retirement date shall be the obtainment of the participant's sixty-second
birthday. His/her normal retirement benefit shall commence on the first day of the
month following his normal retirement date.
(2) The normal retirement benefit shall be 2% of the average monthly compensation
for each year of credited services not to exceed 50% of the monthly wages. The
normal retirement benefit shall be computed to the actual dollars and cents by
application of the above formula. 1
(3) Subject to § 38-8G, the normal retirement benefit shall be payable in the following
manner:
1. Editor's Note: Amended at time of adoption of Code (see Ch. 1, General Provisions, Art. I).
38:4 07 - 01 - 2011
§ 38-8
(4)
(5)
PENSIONS § 38-8
(a) If the participant is unmarried, the normal form of benefit is payable for the
retiree's life as a single life annuity.
(b) If the participant is married, the normal form of benefit is payable as a joint
and fifty-percent survivor annuity. The benefit is payable for the retiree's life.
Upon the death of the retired participant, the retiree's spouse will receive a
survivor benefit equal to 50% of the benefit the retired participant was
receiving. Upon the death of both, the retiree and spouse, all benefits will
cease.
In lieu of the normal form of benefits described in § 38-8A(3), a participant may
elect to have benefits paid in any of the following optional forms of benefits which
shall be the equivalent actuarial value of the benefit provided in accordance with
§ 38-8A(2) and (3):
(a) Joint and one-hundred-percent survivor annuity. Monthly benefit payable
during the participant's lifetime with a provision that if the participant dies
leaving a spouse to whom he was legally married on the annuity's starting
date, a survivor annuity equal to 100% of the annuity payable during the joint
lives of the participant and his spouse shall be paid during the life of and to,
such surviving spouse.
(b) Life annuity, 10 years certain. A monthly benefit payable during the
participant's lifetime with the provision that if the death of the participant
occurs prior to his receipt of 120 monthly payments, monthly payments shall
be continued to his beneficiary until a total of 120 monthly payments in all
have been paid to the participant and his beneficiary. If no designated
beneficiary survives such retired participant, then the commuted value of the
remaining monthly payments shall be paid in a lump sum to the participant's
estate. If the designated beneficiary survives the participant, but dies before
120 payments shall have been paid out as stated above, the commuted value
of the remaining monthly payments shall be paid in a lump sum to the
beneficiary's estate.
Subject to § 38-8A(3) and (4), once a benefit is in pay status the form of benefit
may not be changed for any reason.
B. Postponed retirement.
(1) A participant may postpone his retirement and continue in employment beyond his
normal retirement date.
(2) If a participant does postpone his or her retirement, his monthly benefit shall be
postponed until a date not later than his actual retirement. The Board shall take
whatever action may be necessary to postpone the commencement of income
payments.
(3) The participant's retirement benefit on his actual retirement will be computed in
accordance with § 38-8A(2) using average monthly compensation as of his actual
retirement date.
38:5 07 - OJ - 2011
§ 38-8 BIRDSBORO CODE § 38-8
(4) The benefits payable pursuant to this section shall be paid in accordance with
§ 38-8A(3).
C. Early retirement benefit.
(1) Eligibility. Effective January 1, 2000, a participant who has attained age 59 and
completed I 0 years of service is eligible, upon written notice to the Committee, to
retire and receive an early retirement benefit.
(2) Early retirement date. The participant may elect to have his early retirement benefit
commence on or after his early retirement date which shall be the first day of any
month subsequent to the date he satisfies the requirements of§ 38-8C(l).
(3) Amount. The amount of early retirement benefit shall be the participant's accrued
benefit reduced by 1/180 for the first 60 months and 1/360 for the next 60 months
by which the commencement date of the early retirement benefit precedes the
participant's normal retirement annuity starting date.
(4) The benefits payable under this § 38-8C shall be paid in accordance with
§ 38-8A(3).
D. Disability benefit.
(1) A participant who becomes totally and permanently disabled shall be eligible to
receive a disability retirement benefit.
(2) "Totally and permanently disabled" shall mean a condition of physical or mental
impairment due to which a participant is unable to perform any and every duty of a
gainful occupation for which he is reasonably fitted through training, education and
experience, which continues for a period of at least six months and will be
permanent and continuous for the remainder of the participant's lifetime and due to
which a participant is certified by the Social Security Administration as being
eligible for social security disability benefits.
(3) The disability retirement benefit shall commence the first day of the month that
coincides with or immediately follows the date when the participant's employment
terminates due to total and permanent disability and continuing throughout the
participant's life until the first day of the month in which the participant's death
occurs.
(4) The amount of a participant's disability benefit provided hereunder shall be equal
to his accrued benefit determined as of the date when his employment terminates
due to total and permanent disability and offset by the amount of social security
disability payments received by the participant.
(5) If any person is reemployed subsequent to receiving disability benefits, the
participant shall be credited with years of service and years of credited service
through the period of his total and permanent disability.
E. Death benefit.

(1) Preretirement. In the event of a death of a participant prior to retirement, such
participant's beneficiary shall receive the equivalent actuarial value for the
participant's accrued benefit as determined at such time, payable in either a lump
sum or annuity as provided in§ 38-8A above.
(2) Postretirement death benefit. The postretirement death benefit is payable in
accordance with the form of benefit elected.
F. Accrued benefit and vested benefit.
(1) The accrued benefit of a participant shall be determined in accordance with

(2) Sections 38-8F(3) and (4) and 38-8G apply to any participant whose service is
terminated for any reason other than death, permanent and total disability, normal
or postponed retirement, using the date of such termination as the date of
determination.

(4) Any terminated participant not entitled to a vested benefit shall not be entitled to

G. Commencement of vested benefit payments. A participant who terminates employment

H. Facility of payment. Whenever, in the Retirement Board's opinion, a person entitled to
receive any payment of a benefit or installment thereof hereunder is under a legal
disability or is incapacitated in any way so as to be unable to manage his financial

complete discharge from any liability for the making of such payment under the
provisions of the plan.
I. Beneficiary designation. Each participant will designate the beneficiary to whom the
death benefits, if any, shall be paid in the event of his death prior to retirement. Each
participant has the right, from time to time, to change any designation of beneficiary and
the interest of any beneficiary will be subject to such right. A designation or change of
beneficiary must be in writing on forms supplied by the Retirement Board, and any
beneficiary will not become effective until such change of beneficiary is filed with the
Retirement Board, whether or not the participant is alive at the time of such filing, but
subject to any action taken or payment made on direction of the Retirement Board prior
to such filing. The interest of any beneficiary who dies before the participant will
terminate unless otherwise provided. If a beneficiary is not validly designated, cannot be
found or is not living at the date of payment, any amount payable pursuant to this plan
will be paid to such of the following, in the order named, as the Retirement Board deems
proper: the participant's:
(1) Spouse;
(2) Children per stirpes;
(3) Parents;
(4) Brothers and sisters;
(5) Nephews and nieces, and
( 6) The executors and administrators of the participant's estate.
§ 38-9. Employment of actuary and payments into plan.
A. Borough Council shall employ an actuary and fix the compensation of such actuary and
shall provide for the legal and administrative expenses of the plan. The actuary shall
determine the present liability on account of pensions payable under this article to
employees for service prior to the date of this establishment of the plan. The unfunded
liability shall be paid entirely by the Borough, provided that it may be funded over a
period not exceeding 25 years. The actuary shall determine the amount which shall be
contributed annually to the plan for the service of employees subsequent to the
establishment of the plan, known as "future service costs."
B. The regular contribution of the Borough shall be paid over to the trustee and shall consist
each year of the amount required to fund all the benefits provided under this article
according to the calculations of an independent pension consultant retained by the
Retirement Board, but only to the extent that such funding is not provided under
§ 38-9C.
38:8 07 - 01 - 2011
§ 38-9 PENSIONS § 38-10
C. The contributions shall be delivered to and held by the trustee as provided under the trust
agreement. The trust fund so held by the trustee shall be used to pay benefits and
expenses in accordance with the plan, trust agreement and any agreements with an
insurance company or other financial institution constituting a part of the plan and trust.
D. Any forfeitures occurring as a result of a participant's termination of service, or in any
other manner, shall not be applied to increase the benefits that any participant would
otherwise receive under the plan, and the said forfeitures shall be applied to reduce the
Borough's future contributions and may be anticipated in estimating costs under the plan.
§ 38-10. Fiduciary responsibilities.
A. A Retirement Board is hereby established which shall have general responsibility for the
administration and interpretation of the plan (including, but not limited to, complying
with reporting and disclosure requirements and establishing and maintaining plan
records). The Board shall engage the actuary and such certified public accountants, who
may be accountants for the Borough, as it shall require or deem advisable for the
purposes of the plan. The Board may, with the approval of the Borough, adopt
amendments which, upon the advice of counsel, it deems necessary or advisable to
comply with the law or to facilitate the administration or management of the plan and
which, in the opinion of the actuary selected by the Board, do not significantly increase
the then currently estimated costs of the plan.
B. The trustee shall have the general responsibility under the plan for the management and
control of the assets of the plan. The Retirement Board shall periodically review the
investment performances and methods of the trustee and any other funding agencies,
including any insurance company or insurance companies, under the plan and, with the
approval of the Borough Council, may appoint and remove or change the trustee and any
such finding agency. The Board shall have the power to appoint or remove one or more
investment advisers and to delegate to such adviser authority and discretion to manage
(including the power to acquire and dispose of) the assets of the plan, provided that each
adviser with such authority and discretion shall be either a bank, an insurance company
or a registered investment adviser under the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 and shall
acknowledge in writing that it is a fiduciary with respect to the plan. The Board shall
periodically review the investment performance and methods of each advisor with such
authority and discretion. The Board shall establish investment standards and policies
incorporating any pertinent requirements and objectives of the plan (including any
interest rate or other actuarial assumptions) in its minutes and communicate the same to
the trustee, insurance company or companies or other funding agencies under the plan
and any investment advisers. If annuities are to be purchased under the plan, the Board
shall determine what contracts should be made available to terminated participants or
purchased by the trust.
C. The Retirement Board shall consist of three participants as follows: the President of
Council, the Borough Manager and a representative/participant in the pension plan.
D. The Board shall elect or designate its own Chairman, establish its own bylaws and
procedures with regard to its fiduciary responsibilities and the time and place for its
38:9 07 - 01 - 2011
§ 38-10 BIRDSBORO CODE § 38-10
meetings and provide for the keeping of minutes of all meetings, copies of which shall be
delivered to the Borough. A majority of the participants of the Board shall constitute a
quorum for the transaction of business at a meeting of the Board. Any action of the
Board may be taken upon the affirmative vote of a majority of a quorum of the Board at
a meeting. At the direction of its Chairman, a majority of the Board may vote without a
meeting, by mail, by telegraph or telephone, provided that all of the participants of the
Board are informed by mail or telegraph of their right to vote on the proposal and of the
outcome of the vote thereon.
E. The Board shall appoint a Secretary who may, but need not be, a participant of the
Board. Upon delegation by the Borough, the Secretary shall act as Treasurer of the plan
and shall cause to be kept full and accurate accounts of receipts and disbursement of the
plan, and shall cause to be deposited all funds of the plan to the name and credit of the
plan in such depositories as may be designated by the Board. The Treasurer shall cause
the monies and funds of the plan and trust to be disbursed when so authorized by the
Board pursuant to the terms of the plan and shall perform such other duties as may be
assigned from time to time by the Board.
F. If the payment of any benefit under the plan is provided for by a contract with an
insurance company, the payment of such benefit shall be subject to all the provisions of
such contract.
G. All notices, instructions, designations and other communications from the Borough, a
participant, retired participant or beneficiary to the Board required or permitted under the
plan shall be in such form as is prescribed from time to time by the Board, and shall be
mailed by first class mail or delivered to such locations as shall be specified by the
Board, and shall be deemed to have been duly given and delivered only upon actual
receipt thereof by the Board at such location.
H. All notices, statements, reports and other communications from the Borough or the Board
to any employee, participant, retired participant or beneficiary, required or permitted
under the plan or the law shall be deemed to have been duly given when delivered to, or
when mailed by first-class mail, postage prepaid and addressed to, such employee,
participant, retired participant or beneficiary at his address last appearing on the records
of the Borough, or such other notice shall be given in the manner as may be provided for
by appropriate regulations of the United States Department of Labor or the IRS.
I. The expenses of administering the plan, including the fees and expenses of any employee
of the trust and the trustees under the plan and the reasonable expenses incurred by the
participants of the Board in the performance of its duties under the plan, including, but
not limited to, reasonable compensation for any legal counsel, certified public accountant,
actuary and any other agents of the plan for the cost of services rendered to the plan, and
all other proper charges and disbursements of the trustee or the participants of the Board
(including settlements of claims or legal actions approved by counsel to the plan), shall
be paid out of the trust or other funding agency under the plan if the Borough does not
pay such expenses directly. In estimating costs under the plan, administrative expenses
may be anticipated.
38:10 07 - 01 - 2011
§ 38-10 PENSIONS § 38-10
J. Each participant shall file with the Board such pertinent information concerning himself,
his spouse, beneficiary and contingent annuitant as said Board may specify, and to the
maximum extent permitted by the law, no participant, spouse, beneficiary or contingent
annuitant shall have any rights or be entitled to any benefits under the plan unless such
information is filed by or with respect to him.
K. The Board shall make all determinations as to the right of any person to a benefit under
the plan, claims for benefits under the plan shall be filed with said Board, written
notification of the disposition of a claim shall be furnished reasonably promptly to the
claimant. Any partial or total denial by said Board of a claim for benefits under the plan
by a participant or beneficiary shall be stated in writing by said Board and delivered or
mailed to the participant or beneficiary; and such notice shall set forth the specific
reasons and explanation for the denial. Further, if appropriate, such notice shall contain a
description of any additional material or information necessary for the claimant to perfect
the claim and an explanation why such material or information is necessary and an
explanation of the procedure by which the claimant can obtain a review of the decision.
Any employee, former employee or beneficiary of either, who has been denied a claimed
benefit shall be entitled to review all pertinent documents and upon request to the Board
shall be afforded a reasonable opportunity for a review by said Board of the decision
denying the claim. Such a request for review shall be made in writing and filed with the
Chairman of said Board within a reasonable period, as specified by said Board in writing
from time to time, after the delivery to said claimant of the written notice denying the
claim for benefit. Such written request for review shall contain all additional information
which the claimant wishes the Board to consider. The Board may hold any hearing or
conduct any independent investigation which it deems necessary to render its decision,
and the decision on review shall be made as soon as possible after said Board's receipt of
the request for review. Written notice of the decision on review shall be promptly
furnished to the claimant and shall include specific reasons for such decisions and such
notice shall set forth the specific reasons and explanation for denial of the benefit
written. For all purposes under the plan, such decisions on review (where requested), or
such decisions on claims (where no review is requested), shall be final, binding and
conclusive on all interested persons as to all pertinent matters.
L. To the maximum extent permitted by law, the Borough shall indemnify directly from its
own assets (including the proceeds of any insurance policy the premiums of which are
paid from the Borough's own assets) each participant of the Board and each other officer
or employee of the Borough to whom any duty or power relating to the administration or
interpretation of the plan or to the management and control of the assets of the plan may
be delegated or allocated, against any cost or expense (including counsel fees) or liability
(including any sum paid in settlement of claim with the approval of the Borough) arising
out of any act or omission to act in connection with the plan unless arising out of such
person's own fraud or bad faith.
M. The participants of the Board shall not receive any special compensation for serving in
their capacities as participants of such Board but shall be reimbursed for any reasonable
expenses incurred in connection therewith. Except as otherwise required by law, no bond
or other security need be required of the Board or any participant thereof in any
jurisdiction.
38:11 07 - 01 - 2011
§ 38-11 BIRDSBORO CODE § 38-14
§ 38-11. Nonalienation of benefits; protective provision.
Except insofar as may otherwise be required by law, no benefit under the plan shall be subject
in any manner to anticipation, alienation, sale, transfer, assignment, pledge, encumbrance or
charge, and any attempt so to do shall be void, except as specifically provided in the plan, nor
shall any such benefits be in any manner liable for or subject to garnishment, attachment,
execution, levy or other legal process for the collection of debts or liable for or subject to the
debts, contract, liabilities, engagements or torts of the person entitled to such benefits.
§ 38-12. Amendment of plan and trust.
This plan may be amended at any time, retroactively or prospectively by the Borough Council
subject to 90 days prior notice in writing to the trustee and the Board; provided, however, that
no modifications or amendment which affects rights to any benefits by reason of contributions
theretofore made under the plan shall be made except to the extent necessary or appropriate to
qualify or continue to qualify the plan under the Code or any other law; and provided further
that no modification or amendment shall permit any part of the corpus or income of the fund
to be used for, or diverted to, purposes other than for the exclusive benefit or participants and
their beneficiaries under the plan.
§ 38-13. Inspection of documents.
Notwithstanding any information that is made available by the employer, the Retirement
Board or the trustee to participants of the plan through the distribution of descriptive booklets,
bulletin board notices, payroll notices or oral announcements, any participant of the plan may
examine the plan, the trust agreement and all amendments thereto at the main office of the
employer at such mutually convenient time as is arranged by the participant and a
representative of the employer, the Board or the trustee.
§ 38-14. Designation of Chief Administrative Officer (CAO).
The Borough Manager or designee shall be the Chief Administrative Officer (CAO) of the
plan who shall have primary responsibility for the administration of the administrative affairs
of the pension plan. The duties of the CAO shall be as follows:
A. Supervise and direct the preparation of actuarial reports.
B. Certify and file actuarial valuation reports with the Public Employee Retirement
Commission.
C. Make actuarial report information available to plan membership.
D. Annually determine and submit to the Borough Council of the Borough the financial
requirements of the pension plan and minimum municipal obligation.
E. Provide the Borough Council of the Borough with a cost estimate of the effect of any
proposed benefit plan modification.

§ 38-15 PENSIONS § 38-17
§ 38-15. General provisions.
A. Nothing contained in the plan shall give any employee the right to be retained in the
employment of the employer or any of its subsidiaries or affiliated or associated
corporations or affect the right of any such employer to dismiss any employee. The
adoption and maintenance of the plan shall not constitute a contract between the
employer and any employee or consideration of, or an inducement or to condition of, the
employment of any employee.
B.
c.
The trust shall be the sole source of benefits under the plan and the employer and the
Board assume no liability or responsibility for payment of such benefits, and each
participant, beneficiary or other person who shall claim the right to any payment under
the plan shall be entitled to look only to the trust for such payment and shall not have
any right, claim or demand therefor against the employer, the Board or any participant
thereof or any employee of the employer.
Saving clause. The passage of this article and the repeal by it of any prior enabling
ordinances relating to the establishment and regulation of an Employees Pension Plan of
the Borough of Birdsboro, Berks County, Pennsylvania shall not invalidate the
Retirement Board of the Borough created under such ordinance nor shall it invalidate any
actions of said Board taken under such ordinances. This article, in such respect, shall be
deemed a continuation and codification of such prior enabling ordinances.
ARTICLE II
Police Pension Plan
[Adopted 7-12-2010 by Ord. No. 10-421)
§ 38-16. Establishment of plan.
Pursuant to Act 180 of 1972, as amended, there is hereby established the Borough of
Birdsboro Police Pension Plan (hereinafter referred to as the "plan") to provide for the benefit
of such police employees of the Borough as shall receive an honorable discharge therefrom by
reason of age and service or service disability. The pension allowed to those who are retired
by reason of service-related disabilities shall be in conformity with a uniform scale.
§ 38-17. Definitions.
When used herein, the following terms shall have the following meanings:
ANNIVERSARY DATE - January 1 of each plan year.
AVERAGE MONTHLY COMPENSATION - The monthly average of the compensation
received during the last 36 months of active employment and/or during which the full-time
employee was receiving Heart and Lung Act benefits.
BOROUGH - The Borough of Birdsboro, Berks County, Pennsylvania.

amended or renumbered.
COMPENSATION - Compensation reportable as wages, tips and other compensation on
Federal Form W-2 as required by Sections 6041, 6051 and 6052 of the code, excluding
severance payments, accrued vacation payments, accrued sick day payments, or similar
nonrecurring compensation, and permanent disability and retirement benefits. Compensation
shall include only that compensation which is actually paid to the participant during the
applicable period.
A. In addition, compensation shall also mean employer contributions made pursuant to a

applies to any determination period beginning in such calendar year.

§ 38-18. Eligibility for participation.
Each police officer employee who has attained the age of 21 holding a full-time position in
the Police Department and who works not less than an average of 40 hours per week for a
stated salary or compensation shall become a participant of the plan.
§ 38-19. Credited service for vesting and benefit accrual.
A. In general. Except as provided in Section 3.5, a person is credited with all periods of
service in which he/she is employed by the Employer (or any Related Employer) as an
Employee, including working days, vacation, sick days, holidays, bereavement days, jury
duty time, and nonscheduled days (such as weekends or the equivalent).
B. Intervening military service.
(1) With six months of more of prior service. Any member of the police force of the
Borough of Birdsboro who has been a regularly appointed employee of the
Department for a period of six months, and who thereafter shall enter into the
military service of the United States, shall have credited to his or her employment
record for pension or disability benefits all of the time spent by him or her in such
service of the United States military if such person returns or has heretofore
returned to his or her employment within six months after his or her separation
from the service .
38:15 07 - 01 - 2011
§38-19 BIRDSBORO CODE § 38-20
(2) With less than six months of prior service. Any member of the police force who
was employed by the Department for less than six months before leaving to enter
the military service of the United States shall have such military service credited
for the pension or disability benefits, provided:
(a) The person returns to employment with the employer (or any related
employer) at a time when the employer (or any related employer) is legally
obligated to reemploy the person under the Uniformed Services Employment
and Reemployment Rights Act of 1994, 38 U.S.C. § 4301 et seq., and any
amendments, supplements, or successor legislation; and
(b) Such person pays to the plan the amount of employee contributions that such
person would have had to make had he been employed by the employer
during the time he was in military service. Any payment to the plan shall be
made during the period beginning with the date of reemployment and whose
duration is three times the period of the person's service in the military, not
to exceed five years.
C. Nonintervening military service. There are no plan provisions for nonintervening military
service.
D. Back pay. A person is also credited with service during any period for which back pay,
irrespective of mitigation of damages, is either awarded or agreed to be the employer.
E. Exclusions. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained in this document, a
person shall not receive credit for service:
( 1) During any layoff, including temporary layoffs; or
(2) Within any unpaid leave of absence, except for certain military service as provided
in Subsections B and C.
§ 38-20. Benefits.
A. Normal retirement.
(1) Normal retirement date. The normal retirement date for a participant shall be the
first day of the month following the 50th birthday, provided the participant has
completed 25 years of credited service.
(2) Amount of normal retirement benefit. The retirement benefit of a participant shall
be equal to 1/2 of his average monthly compensation continuing for life in equal
monthly payments and ceasing in the month of death.
(3) Service increment benefit. A participant who retires with service in excess of 25
years shall have his pension increased by $50 a month for each full year of service
in excess of 25 years. The maximum service increment benefit for services over 25
years shall be $100 per month.
B. Postponed retirement. A participant may elect to postpone his retirement beyond his
normal retirement date. His postponed retirement benefit will be computed in the same
38:16 07 - 01 - 2011
§ 38-20 PENSIONS § 38-20
manner as the normal retirement benefit, using compensation to the postponed retirement
date.
C. Early retirement. There are no plan provisions for an early retirement benefit.
D. Permanent, service-related disability retirement.
(1) Eligibility. If a participant shall qualify for a permanent and total service-related
disability benefit under the provisions of the plan, and such service-related
disability is confirmed by the Police Pension Board, such police officer shall be
eligible to receive a disability benefit from the plan.
(2) Disability retirement date. The disability retirement date for a participant shall be
the first day of the month following the date of the service-related disability.
(3) Amount of disability benefit.
(a) In the event of permanent, service-related disability, benefits shall become
payable to an injured police officer in an amount equal to 75% of the police
officer's salary at the time the disability was incurred, provided that any
police officer who received benefits for the same injuries under the Social
Security Act ( 49 Stat. 620, 42 U.S.C. § 30 l et seq.) shall have the disability
benefit offset or reduced by the amount of such social security benefits.
(b) "Total and permanent disability" means a physical or mental condition of a
member resulting from bodily injury or disease or mental disorder contracted,
without fault or misconduct on such officer's part, from the performance of
such officer's duties in the Police Department, which renders the member
incapable of continuing in the employment as a police officer of the
Borough. The determination that a police officer is totally and permanently
disabled shall be made by the Borough or its designated agent. Before
making such determination, the Borough or its designated agent shall secure
the opinion of one or more practicing physicians licensed to practice
medicine in the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania. The Borough shall have the
right to require a physical examination and a redetermination at its option.
E. Death benefits.
(1) Qualification for death benefit. The beneficiaries [as defined in Subsection E(3)] of
a police officer shall be entitled to receive a death benefit if the police officer dies:
(a) After he/she has begun receiving benefits under a normal retirement benefit;
or
(b) After he/she has begun receiving disability retirement benefits, provided that
such benefits did not terminate prior to his/her death because he/she ceased to
be disabled; or
(c) While still employed by the Borough and after having met the age and
service requirements for normal retirement; or
38:17 07 - 01 - 2011
§ 38-20 BIRDSBORO CODE § 38-20
( d) Prior to commencement of any retirement benefit under this section and was
vested in his/her accrued benefit.2
(2) Death benefit: form and amount of payments. The death benefit shall be paid in a
series of monthly payments:
(a) Beginning on the first day of the month following the month of the police
officer's death under the conditions described in Subsection E(l)(a), (b) or
(c); or
(b) Beginning on the first day of the month following the expected normal
retirement date of the deceased police officer and described in Subsection
E(l )( d); and
(c) Continuing on the first day of each succeeding month until there 1s no
surviving person who qualifies as a beneficiary; or
( d) In a monthly amount equal to:
[1] Fifty percent of the monthly amount being received by the police officer
at the time of his/her death, or would have been receiving that the
police officer been retired at the date of death, described in Subsection
E(l)(a), (b) or (c); or
[2] Fifty percent of the monthly vested accrued amount the Police Officer
would have been entitled to receive described in Subsection E(l)(d).3
(3) Beneficiaries.
(a) For purposes of the death benefit, the "beneficiary" of a police officer shall
be his/her spouse. If there is no spouse or if the spouse survives and
subsequently dies, then the death benefit shall be payable to the police
officer's child or children who have not yet attained age 18 (or are attending
college and have not yet attained age 23). For purposes of this subsection, a
person is "attending college" if he/she is registered at an accredited institution
of higher learning and is carrying a minimum course load of seven credit
hours per semester. Where there is no surviving spouse, the death benefit
shall be payable to eligible children in equal shares. [Amended 4-11-2001
by Ord. No. 428)
(b) For purposes of the death benefit return of contributions in Subparagraph
E(4), the beneficiary(ies) shall be the spouse or eligible children as above
stated. In the case where there is no spouse or eligible children, the
participant may designate by last will and testament or codicil thereto, or
through a standard form document duly approved by the plan administrator,
2. Editor's Note: The original subsection regarding the killed in service death benefits, which immediately followed this
subsection, was deleted 4-11-2011 by Ord. No. 428.
3. Editor's Note: Original Subsection 4.SC, Killed in service death benefit, which immediately followed this subsection,
