limitation on users which are using dilution to meet applicable pretreatment standards or
requirements, or in other cases where the imposition of mass limitations are appropriate.
P. Containing any substance which will cause the sewage treatment plant to violate its
NPDES permit or the receiving water quality standards, causing pass-through or
interference.
Q. Containing any substance which may cause the sewage treatment plant effluent or any
other product of the sewage treatment plant thereof such as residues, biosolids or scums
to be unsuitable for reclamation and reuse or to interfere with the reclamation process. In
no case, shall a substance discharged to the sewer system cause the sewage treatment
plant to be in noncompliance with biosolids use or disposal criteria, guidelines or
regulations developed under § 405 of the Clean Water Act, any criteria, guidelines or
regulations affecting biosolids use or disposal developed pursuant to the Solid Waste
Disposal Act, the Clean Air Act, the Toxic Substances Control Act or a P ADEP criteria
applicable to the biosolids management method being used.
§ 303-39. Special agreements.
Nothing in this section shall be construed as preventing any special agreement or arrangement
between the Borough and any user of the sewer system whereby wastewater of unusual
strength or character is accepted into the sewer system should such wastewater be deemed by
the Borough to be acceptable for treatment without harm to the sewage treatment plant or
operating personnel. Special agreements are allowed only if the wastewater is within
acceptable levels according to state and/or federal laws and regulations. Each special
agreement must first be approved by the EPA as a substantial modification under 40 CFR
403.18.
303:23 07 - 01 - 2011
§ 303-40 BIRDSBORO CODE § 303-42
§ 303-40. Plumbing inspection.
A. The Borough hereby reserves the right to inspect any building sewer, lateral or collecting
sewer that discharges wastewater, directly or indirectly, to the Borough's facilities to
determine compliance with this part.
B. Such inspections shall occur:
(1) At the discretion of the Borough, upon reasonable cause to believe that a violation
of the above-referenced Borough ordinance(s) has occurred.
(2) At the time of transfer of title to a said structure connected to the said sewer
system.
C. The cost of such inspection shall be borne by the Borough unless such inspection
discloses an illegal connection or other noncompliance, in which case the cost will be
billed by the Borough to the current owner of the structure connected to the sewer
system as part of the final sewer bill rendered to the owner or, in the event no final bill is
rendered, to the current owner.
D. In the event that such inspection discloses an illegal connection to the collection system
or other noncompliance with applicable Borough ordinances, a written notice of such
noncompliance signed by the Borough Plumbing Inspector shall be posted on the front
door of the property and mailed to the owner. The current owner of the property shall
bear all costs for removal, remediation and/or abatement of any violation(s) found and of
bringing the property into compliance with the aforementioned ordinance(s) and/or
regulations, even if the current property owner was not responsible for creating such a
condition. Where such conditions exist, they shall be remedied in a manner approved by
the Borough within 30 days of receipt by the owner or authorized agent of the owner or
individual in charge of a notice from the Borough.
§ 303-41. Access.
The Borough shall the right of access at all times to any part of any improved property served
by the sewer system and to any control manholes as shall be required for purposes of this
inspection, observation, measurement, sampling and testing of sewage and for performance of
other functions relating to service rendered by the Borough through the sewer system.
§ 303-42. Responsibility for obstructions in sewer laterals.
A. When an obstruction in the sewer lateral conveying sanitary sewage from an improved
property to the Borough sewer system occurs, it shall be the responsibility of the owner
of the improved property to determine first if the obstruction is located in that portion
located on the owner's property, that is, the portion of the sewage disposal system located
in the building sewer line extending from the building or structure to the property line
(building sewer), and to clear the same at the owner's expense.
B. Upon determination that the obstruction is located at a point from the property line to the
main sewer line (Borough lateral) or if the location of the obstruction cannot be
303:24 07 - 01 - 2011
§ 303-42 SEWERS AND SEWAGE DISPOSAL § 303-45
determined by the owner, the Borough shall be notified, at which time the Borough shall
assume responsibility for locating and removing the obstruction from the line at its
expense in order to protect the integrity of the sewer lateral and the sewer system.
C. The Borough reserves the right to assess damages, including the cost of removing the
obstruction, against the owner if it is determined that the obstruction was caused by an
object introduced into the system from the improved property which is not authorized or
expected to be in the system or if the obstruction is located in the portion of the line
which is the responsibility of the owner.
D. No person or entity shall attempt to or remove any obstruction from the sewer line or
Borough lateral unless authorized by the Borough.
§ 303-43. Responsibility for tenant's actions.
The owner of each improved property connected to the sewer system shall be responsible for
all acts of tenants or other occupants of such improved property insofar as such acts shall be
governed by provisions of this part.
§ 303-44. Right to refuse connection to or to compel the discontinuance of use of the
sewer system.
The Borough reserves the right to refuse to any person the privilege of connection of any
improved property to the sewer system or to compel the discontinuance of use of a sewer and
the sewer system by any person in order to prevent discharges into the sewer system of any
wastes deemed to be harmful to the sewer system or to have a deleterious effect on sewage
treatment processes.
§ 303-45. Suspension of wastewater treatment services.
A. The Borough may suspend the wastewater treatment services to a user and/or a user's
industrial waste discharge permit when such suspension is necessary, in the opinion of
the Borough, in order to stop an actual or threatened discharge which presents or may
present an imminent or substantial endangerment to the health or welfare of persons, to
the environment, causes interference to the sewage treatment plant, damage to the sewer
system or causes the Borough to violate any condition of its NPDES permit. Said
suspension may take place after informal notice to the user.
B. Any person notified of a suspension of wastewater treatment service and/or of an
industrial waste discharge permit shall immediately stop or eliminate the contributions. In
the event of a failure of the person to comply voluntarily with the suspension order, the
Borough may take such steps as deemed necessary, including immediate severance of the
sewer connection, to prevent or minimize damage to the sewer system, the sewage
treatment plant or endangerment to individuals.
C. The Borough shall reinstate the industrial waste discharge permit and/or wastewater
treatment service upon proof of the elimination of the noncomplying discharge.
303:25 07 - 01 - 2011
§ 303-46 BIRDSBORO CODE § 303-49
§ 303-46. Additional rules and regulations.
The Borough reserves the right to adopt, from time to time, such additional rules and
regulations as it shall deem necessary and proper in connection with use and operation of the
sewer system, which rules and regulations shall become effective as though set forth herein.
§ 303-47. Violations and penalties.
Any person, firm or corporation who shall violate any provision of this part shall, upqn
conviction thereof, be sentenced to pay a fine of not more than $1,000 plus costs and, in
default of payment of said fine and costs, to a term of imprisonment not to exceed 30 days.
Each day that a violation of this part continues shall constitute a separate offense.
ARTICLE V
Admission of Industrial Waste into Sewer System
§ 303-48. Desirability of combined treatment.
The economy and desirability of the combined treatment of industrial waste and domestic
sewage is recognized. However, not all types of industrial waste can be so treated. Hence, it
shall be the established policy of the Borough to accept those types and quantities that are not
harmful or damaging to the structures, processes or operation of the sewer system and/or
sewage treatment plant or are not specifically prohibited by this article. It is also recognized
that, to provide this service, additional expenditures are required. These must be borne by
those persons receiving the benefits.
§ 303-49. Approval required for industrial wastes.
A. Prior review and approval of the Borough shall be required for the discharge into the
sewer system of wastewater having any one or more of the following characteristics:
(1) A five-day BOD greater than 300 milligrams per liter (mg/I).
(2) A suspended solids content greater than 300 milligrams per liter (mg/I).
(3) A dissolved solids content greater than 500 milligrams per liter (mg/I).
(4) A COD greater than 600 milligrams per liter (mg/I).
(5) A chlorine demand greater than 12 milligrams per liter (mg/I).
(6) An average daily flow greater than 5% of the average daily sanitary sewage flow
of the sewer system.
(7) Any quantity of substances possessing characteristics described in § 303-38 of this
part.
(8) Having been discharged from an industrial establishment, as this term is defined in
§ 303-3 of this chapter.
303:26 07 - 01 - 2011
§ 303-49 SEWERS AND SEW AGE DISPOSAL § 303-50
(9) Being classified as a significant industrial user.
B. Said approval of the Borough shall be in the form of an industrial waste discharge
permit.
§ 303-50. Industrial waste discharge permits.
A. Prior to discharging said waste to the sewer system, or prior to continuing the discharge
of said waste to the sewer system after the effective date of this part, the owner of the
property from which such discharge is proposed to be made shall apply to Borough
Council, in writing, for a permit to make such a discharge.
B. Such application shall be made on industrial waste discharge permit application forms
furnished by the Borough. Said forms shall contain all pertinent data, including, but not
limited to, estimated or actual quantity of flow, character of waste, maximum rate of
discharge and proposed pretreatment facilities, together with any plans, specifications or
other information considered pertinent in the judgment of the Borough.
C. The industrial waste discharge permit application forms shall be competently completed
and returned to Borough Council for review and approval. Only upon approval of
Borough Council will an industrial waste discharge permit be issued and the discharge
allowed.
D. Where necessary, in the opinion of the Borough, the property owner shall provide, at his
expense, a survey analysis and report by a registered professional engineer acceptable to
Council.
E. Upon review of the industrial waste discharge permit application, the Borough will issue
to the applicant an industrial waste discharge permit should the applicant's waste be
suitable for treatment, in the judgment of the Borough. Said permit is not transferable
without the prior written consent of the Borough.
F. As the EPA adds or amends specific pretreatment and effluent guidelines, or as the
Borough deems necessary, the restrictions or conditions of a permit may require
amendment as circumstances dictate. The Borough reserves the right to make such
amendments as necessary in the judgment of the Borough.
G. The Borough may suspend a permit when such suspension is necessary, in the judgment
of the Borough, in order to stop a discharge which presents a hazard to the public health,
safety or welfare; to the environment at the Borough's sewer system or sewage treatment
plant; or upon a finding by the Borough that the discharger has violated any provision of
this article. Any discharger ·notified of such a suspension shall immediately stop the
discharge of all wastewater into the Borough's system. The Borough shall reinstate the
permit upon proof of satisfactory compliance of all discharges with this article.
H. Permits shall be issued for a specific time period not to exceed 10 years. If the permittee
is not notified by the Borough 90 days prior to the expiration date of the permit, the
permit shall automatically be extended for one year.
I. A permit may be revoked by the Borough for any of the following causes:
303:27 07 - 01 - 2011
§ 303-50 BIRDSBORO CODE § 303-52
(1) Failure of a permittee to accurately report his wastewater characteristics.
(2) Failure of a permittee to report significant changes in operation which affect
wastewater characteristics.
(3) Refusal of reasonable access to the permittee's premises for the ~urpose of
inspection or monitoring.
(4) Violations of the conditions of the permit or of this article.
§ 303-51. Screening and equalization tanks.
A. Industrial establishments shall install fine screens to remove husks, hulls, vegetable skins,
peelings, threads, lint, grease and other such nonsettleable and floating solids, or other
organic or inorganic substances, determined by the Borough to overload, impair the
efficiency of or cause difficulties in operation of the sewage treatment plant used to treat
and dispose of the wastes or in maintaining required quality of treatment plant effluent.
B. Any improved property discharging 50,000 gallons or more of domestic sewage and/or
industrial waste per day into the sewer system and having large variations in the rate of
discharge of such within a twenty-four-hour period shall install suitable holding tanks for
equalizing the rate of discharge more uniformly over the entire twenty-four-hour period.
The average rate of discharge during any twenty-four-hour period shall not be exceeded
by more than 50% at any time during such tweµty-four-hour period.
§ 303-52. Preliminary treatment and handling of industrial wastes.
A. Whenever necessary, in the opinion of the Borough, the owner of an improved property
shall provide, at his expense, such facilities for preliminary treatment and handling of
industrial waste as may be necessary to:
(1) Reduce BOD to 300 milligrams per liter (mg/I), suspended solids to 300 mg/I
and/or dissolved solids to 500 mg/I.
(2) Reduce objectionable characteristics or constituents to come within the maximum
limits permitted in this part.
(3) Control the quantities and rates of discharge over a twenty-four--hour day and a
seven-day week.
B. Plans, specifications and any other pertinent information relating to proposed facilities for
preliminary treatment and handling of industrial waste shall be submitted for approval to
the Borough, and no construction of any such facility shall be commenced until approval
thereof first shall have been obtained, in writing, from the Borough and until approval
thereof first shall have been obtained from any governmental regulatory body having
jurisdiction. Such approvals shall not relieve the discharger from meeting any of the
limitations of this article.
C. Whenever facilities for preliminary treatment and handling of industrial waste shall have
been provided by the owner of such improved property, such facilities shall continuously
303:28 07 - 01 - 2011
§ 303-52 SEWERS AND SEW AGE DISPOSAL § 303-55
be maintained, at the expense of such owner, in satisfactory operating conditions, and the
Borough shall have access to such facilities at reasonable times for purposes of
inspection and testing.
D. The Borough reserves the right to refuse permission to connect to the sewer system, to
compel discontinuance of use of the sewer system or to compel pretreatment of industrial
waste in order to prevent discharges deemed harmful to or having a deleterious effect
upon any portion of the sewer system or treatment plant.
§ 303-53. Changes in industrial processes.
Any person discharging wastes covered by an industrial waste discharge permit and who
proposes a change in the method of operation or other factors which will alter the type of
waste then being discharged into the sewer system shall apply for a new industrial waste
discharge permit at least 30 days prior to such a change. Such person shall notify the
Borough, in writing, at least 10 days prior to such change, so that the Borough can sample the
industrial waste immediately after such change takes place.
§ 303-54. Measurement of pollutant concentrations of industrial wastes.
A. Industrial waste being discharged into the sewer system shall be subject to periodic
sampling and inspection to be used as a basis for determining additional charges due to
excessive concentrations of dissolved solids, suspended solids, BOD and/or ammonia
nitrogen. Such sampling and inspection shall be made by the Borough as frequently as
may be deemed necessary. The analysis of the sample so obtained shall be the basis for
computing additional charges in accordance with Part 4, Article X, of this chapter. The
cost of said sampling shall not be borne by the industrial user.
B. The industrial user may request that samples be taken in addition to the normal periodic
samples taken by the Borough. The cost of making this collection and analysis shall be
paid by the industrial user.
C. All sampling shall be of a representative manner and shall be taken by a method
approved by a registered professional engineer.
D. Sampling facilities shall be accessible to the Borough at all reasonable times.
E. The analysis of samples obtained shall be made in accordance with the latest edition of
"Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Sewage" published by the
American Public Health Association.
§ 303-55. Control manholes.
When required by the Borough, the owner of any property discharging industrial waste to the
sewer system shall install a suitable manhole together with such necessary meters and other
appurtenances in the building sewer serving such industrial establishment to facilitate
observation, sampling and measurement of such industrial waste. Such manhole, when
required, shall be accessible and safely located and shall be constructed in accordance with
303:29 07-01-2011
§ 303-55 BIRDSBORO CODE § 303-57
plans approved by the Borough. The manhole shall be installed by the property owner, at his
expense, and shall be maintained by him so as to be safe and accessible at all times.
§ 303-56. Right to compel pretreatment of industrial waste.
The Borough reserves the right to compel the pretreatment of an industrial waste, in order to
prevent discharges into the sewer system of any wastes deemed to be harmful to the sewer
system or to have a deleterious effect on sewage treatment processes.
ARTICLE VI
Sewage Hauling
§ 303-57. Removal, transportation and disposal of domestic waste and industrial waste.
Any tank truck or any other equipment used or intended to be used within the Borough for the
removal and/or transportation of domestic wastes shall conform to the following requirements:
A. The container shall be watertight.
B. Tanks, containers or other equipment shall be so constructed that every portion of the
interior and exterior can be easily cleaned and shall be kept in a clean and sanitary
condition.
C. Piping, valves and permanent or flexible connections shall be accessible and easily
disconnected for cleaning purposes.
D. The inlet opening, or openings, to every container shall be so constructed that the
material will not spill out during the filling, transfer or transport.
E. The outlet connections shall be so constructed that no material will leak out or run out to
other than the point of discharge and shall be of a design and type suitable for the
material handled and capable of controlling the flow or discharge without spillage, undue
spray or flooding of immediate surroundings while in use.
F. No connection shall be made at any time between a tap or outlet furnishing potable water
on any premises and any container or equipment holding material by any means other
than an open connection. No domestic waste and/or nondomestic/industrial waste shall be
discharged by tank trucks into the sewer system.
303:30 07 - 01 - 2011
§ 303-57 SEWERS AND SEW AGE DISPOSAL § 303-60
Part 4
Sewer Rentals and Charges
ARTICLE VII
Costs of Construction and Connection
§ 303-58. Responsibility for connection costs.
All costs and expenses of construction of a building sewer and all costs and expenses of
connection of a building sewer to a sewer shall be borne by the owner of the improved
property to be connected, and such owner shall indemnify and save harmless the Borough
from all loss or damage that may be occasioned, directly or indirectly, as a result of
construction of a building sewer or of connection of a building sewer to a sewer.
§ 303-59. Tapping fee.
A. A tapping fee per residential unit, as set by the Borough, is hereby imposed on any
property owner connecting such residential unit directly or indirectly, as part of new
construction, to the sewer system. Such fee shall be charged, due and owing in addition
to all other permit costs, application fees and expenses resulting from such new
construction. The Borough retains the right to amend this article, from time to time, to
change the amount of the tapping fee specified herein.
B. An estimated daily use tapping fee will be charged based on a valid estimate (as
reviewed and approved by the Borough Engineer using industry standards as a guide)
shall be charged any nondomestic user, including commercial, industrial and institutional
users for service, connecting directly or indirectly to the sewer system as part of new
construction, or as a result of increased usage and service over previously reserved
allocated capacity. Such fee shall be charged, due and owing in addition to all other
permit costs, application fees and expenses resulting from such new construction or
increased usage over previous reserved or allocated capacity. In the event the
measurement of a nondomestic user's estimate of daily use exceeds that on which the
tapping fee was based, on a ninety-day-average-daily-flow basis (i.e., the average daily
flow shall be determined by obtaining the sum of the daily total sewage flow for any
consecutive 90 days and dividing that sum by 90, or for six thirty-day periods within one
calendar year); then, in any such event, the nondomestic user shall purchase such
additional flow capacities equal to user's actual use, which additional flow capacities to
be purchased shall be based upon the mean average of the test criteria set forth above,
provided such capacity is available from the sewage treatment plant.
§ 303-60. Connection fee.
A. A connection fee to cover the Borough's cost of providing a lateral from the sewer to the
improved property to be connected to the sewer system, as set by the Borough, is hereby
imposed on any property owner intending to connect, directly or indirectly, as part of
new construction, to the sewer system. Such fee shall be charged, due and owing in
addition to all other costs, fees and expenses resulting from such new construction. The
303:31 07 - 01 - 2011
§ 303-60 BIRDSBORO CODE § 303-62
Borough retains the right to amend this article, from time to time, to change the amount
of the connection fee specified herein.
B. The Borough, at its option, may elect to authorize the owner's plumbing contractor to
construct the lateral required to connect the improved property referred to in Subsection
A to the sewer system. In this case, the owner of the improved property shall be
responsible for all costs charged by the plumbing contractor, and no additional
connection fee shall be charged to the owner by the Borough. The owner of such
improved property shall indemnify and save harmless the Borough from all loss or
damage that may be occasioned by the Borough, directly or indirectly, as a result of the
connection of such improved property to such sewer.
§ 303-61. Permit and inspection fee.
A. A permit fee to cover the Borough's administrative cost of issuing a permit for
connection to the sewer system, as set by resolution, is hereby imposed on any property
owner intending to connect, directly or indirectly, as part of new construction, to the
sewer system. Such fee shall be charged, due and owing in addition to all other costs,
fees and expenses resulting from such new construction. The Borough retains the right to
amend this article, from time to time, to change the amount of the permit fee specified
herein.
B. An inspection fee to cover the Borough's costs of inspecting, witnessing the testing of,
and approving the building sewer upon completion of construction, as set by resolution,
is hereby imposed on any property owner intending to connect, directly or indirectly, as
part of new construction, to the sewer system. Such fee shall be charged, due and owing
in addition to all other costs, fees and expenses resulting from such new construction.
The Borough retains the right to amend this article, from time to time, to change the
amount of the inspection fee specified herein.
ARTICLE VIII
Sewer Rentals and Charges
§ 303-62. Sewer rentals and charges imposed.
A. Sewer rentals or sewer user charges for the use of the sewer system are hereby imposed
upon and shall be collected from the owner of each improved property located within the
Borough which shall be connected to the sewer system, whether such use of the sewer
system or the connection thereto or the benefit resulting from such use or connection
shall be direct or indirect.
B. Such sewer rentals or charges shall commence and shall be effective on the date of
connection of such improved property to the sewer system or on the date when the
Borough first shall be capable of accepting domestic sewage and industrial waste from
such improved property for transportation and treatment, whichever date last shall occur.
C. Such sewer rentals or charges shall be payable quarterly as hereinafter in this article
provided.
303:32 07 - 01 - 2011
§ 303-62 SEWERS AND SEW AGE DISPOSAL § 303-65
D. Each billing unit located in one building or on one improved property shall be billed and
considered as a separate billing unit, irrespective of the fact that each such room, group
of rooms or enclosure in such building or on such improved property shall be owned by
the same person and irrespective of the fact that each such billing unit is not connected
separately and independently with the sewer system.
§ 303-63. Metered service.
A. Except upon special written permission granted by the Borough and upon good cause
shown, each connection unit shall be required to have installed a water meter or water
meters to measure the quantity of water used by such connection unit for the purpose of
computing sewer rentals or charges hereunder.
B. Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, sewer rentals or charges for domestic
wastes and nondomestic wastes discharged into the sewer system from any improved
property shall be based upon the volume of water usage, adjusted, if appropriate, as
provided in this chapter, based upon the metered volume of water used at such improved
property, whether in connection with the applicable water system or otherwise.
C. Sewer rentals or charges for domestic waste and nondomestic waste discharged into the
sewer system from any improved property may be based upon actual metered volume of
domestic waste and nondomestic waste discharge, as permitted in this article .
§ 303-64. Nonmetered service.
Sewer rentals or charges for domestic waste and nondomestic waste discharged into the sewer
system from any improved property or any billing unit located therein, when the volume of
water usage is not metered in connection with any water system and when the actual volume
of discharge is not metered as permitted in this article, shall be based upon an estimate by the
Borough of the water consumption of said improved property or billing unit and computed on
the basis of such estimate in accordance with the method set forth under § 303-63.
§ 303-65. Multiple users.
A. Each billing unit located in a multiple unit shall be billed as a separate entity, and the
metered rate schedule and minimum sewer rental or charge shall be used in computing
the sewer rentals or charges applicable to each such billing unit.
B. In any case where the Borough grants written permission for more than one billing unit
to be served through a common water meter or through a common sewage discharge
meter for the purpose of computing sewer rentals or charges hereunder, a multiple rental
or charge per quarter shall be imposed, which rental or charge shall be calculated in the
following manner:
(1) The total consumption of water through such common water meter or the total
discharge through such common sewage discharge meter shall be divided by the
number of billing units served thereby;
303:33 07 - 01 - 2011
§ 303-65 BIRDSBORO CODE § 303-68
(2) The metered rate schedule for computing sewer rentals or charges referred to under
§ 303-69 shall be applied to the resultant quotient; and
(3) The resultant pro rata rental or charge for each billing unit shall be multiplied by
the number of such billing units receiving water service through such common
water meter or discharging sewage through such common sewage discharge meter
to arrive at the total bill for all such billing units served through the common
meter; provided, however, that there shall be charged a minimum sewer rental or
charge for each such billing unit.
§ 303-66. Discharge of potable water into watercourses other than the sewer system.
A. All nondomestic waste users of the sewer system within the Borough which have
substantial portions of their potable water use discharged, uncontaminated, to conduits or
watercourses other than the sewer system shall install and maintain a meter, of design
and quality suitable to the Borough Engineer, on all pipelines so used.
B. Readings or the recordings of these meters shall be made concurrent with regular water
meter readings. For purposes of billing these nondomestic users for sewer service, the
Borough will deduct the reading of the second meter for water not discharged into the
sewer system from the potable water meter before sewer rentals or charges are computed.
§ 303-67. Cost of sample analysis.
A. All costs incurred by the Borough in collecting and analyzing samples in connection with
determining a strong waste discharge or with monitoring nondomestic waste to determine
compliance with Article IX of this chapter shall be billed by the Borough directly to the
nondomestic user whose wastewater is sampled.
B. Such user may request that additional samples be taken in addition to the normal periodic
samples taken by the Borough. The cost of collecting any such normal or additional
samples and making the analysis shall be borne by the user/owner.
§ 303-68. Charge for failure to comply with provisions.
If the owner of any improved property shall fail to provide the Borough with the complete
information required to compute the sewer rentals or charges to such improved property, or
additional tapping fees to be charged, if applicable, the Borough may estimate a reasonable
applicable sewer rental or charge and additional tapping fees, as applicable, for such improved
property and such estimated sewer rentals or charges or additional tapping fee shall be the
actual sewer rentals or charges or tapping fee payable until the required information is filed;
provided, however, that no rebate shall be paid by the Borough if the information filed reveals
lower sewer rentals or charges or tapping fee, where applicable, than that estimated by the
Borough. But if the facts indicate higher sewer rentals or charges or tapping fee were
warranted by the terms hereof, such additional sewer rentals or charges or tapping fee, where
applicable, shall be paid by the user.
303:34 07 - 01 - 2011
§ 303-69 SEWERS AND SEW AGE DISPOSAL § 303-71
§ 303-69. Amount and manner of computation of sewer rentals and charges.
A. Sewer rentals and charges for sewage discharged into the sewer system from any
improved property shall be based upon and shall be computed in accordance with the
Borough's current metered rate schedule, which shall be established by separate
ordinance.
B. Additional classifications and sewer rentals or charges therefor or modifications of the
current schedule of sewer rentals or charges may be established by the Borough, from
time to time, as deemed necessary.
C. Notwithstanding the foregoing, in as much as nondomestic waste may be stronger and
more difficult to treat than domestic waste, additional sewer rentals or charges may be
imposed, from time to time, by the Borough for nondomestic waste discharged into the
sewer system. The Borough hereby reserves the right to regulate the discharge of
nondomestic waste into the sewer system, to establish and impose additional sewer
rentals or charges for nondomestic waste discharged into the sewer system and to
promulgate such rules and regulations governing the volume and concentration of
nondomestic waste discharged into the sewer system and the measurement thereof as
may be deemed necessary from time to time.
§ 303-70. Excessive sewer maintenance expense.
Any person discharging any waste which in the judgment of the Borough causes any
extraordinary maintenance, expenses shall be billed by the Borough in the amount of said
expenses. The billing amount shall be determined by the Borough and shall include charges
for labor of Borough personnel.
ARTICLE IX
Strong Waste Surcharge
§ 303-71. Additional charges for strong wastes.
A. There shall be additional charges for nondomestic wastes discharged to the sewer system
from any industry, business or commercial enterprise and having total suspended solids,
BOD5, and/or ammonia nitrogen of normal domestic waste. Normal domestic waste
(normal strength waste) shall be defined as having the following concentrations:
(1) BOCs: 300 milligrams per liter (mg/l).
(2) Total suspended solids: 300 mg/l.
(3) Ammonia nitrogen: 25 mg/l.
B. The shall be no strong waste surcharges applied to domestic wastes.
303:35 07 - 01 - 2011
§ 303-72 BIRDSBORO CODE § 303-73
§ 303-72. Surcharge formula.
A. In order to determine the additional charge for nondomestic wastes with strength greater
than that of normal domestic waste, the following formula shall be used:
Sq= 0.00834 Q1 [BOD5 - 300) TA+ (SS 1 - 300) TB+ NH3N - 25) TC]
Where:
Sq= the quarterly surcharge to be added to the quarterly sewer rental or charge
0.00834 = a constant to convert waste strength expressed in mg/I to thousand
pounds of waste
Q, = the quarterly volume of nondomestic waste flow expressed in millions of
gallons
BODs = the 5-day BOD of the nondomestic waste expressed in mg/I
SS, = the total suspended solids in mg/I of the nondomestic waste
NHJN = the ammonia nitrogen in mg/I of the nondomestic waste
300, 300 and 25 = constants expressing waste-load strength of domestic waste in
mg/I for the respective pollutant parameters
TA represents the cost incurred by the Borough in treating 1,000 pounds of BOD5;
TB represents the cost of treating 1,000 pounds of total suspended solids; and TC
represents the cost of treating 1,000 pounds of ammonia nitrogen. TA, TB and TC
vary each year as sewage treatment plant operations and maintenance costs change.
Therefore, TA, TB and TC shall be determined at the beginning of each year by the
Borough, based upon budgeted operating costs, and adopted by ordinance.
B. When a value of BODs and/or total suspended solids of a nondomestic waste is less than
300 milligrams per liter (mg/I), the value of 300 shall be used in the calculation of the
strong waste discharge in place of the actual value which is less than 300 milligrams per
liter (mg/I). When a value of ammonia nitrogen is less than 25 milligrams per liter
(mg/I), the value of 25 shall be used in the calculation in place of the actual value which
is less than 25 milligrams per liter (mg/I).
§ 303-73. Inspection, sampling and analysis.
A. Representative sampling point. All users proposing to discharge or intending to continue
to discharge commercial or industrial wastewater to any part of the sewer system must
make available a sampling point representative of the discharge which is acceptable to,
and approved by, the Borough. This point must be available to the Borough and its duly
authorized agents, P ADEP or EPA, for purposes of conducting sampling inspections,
compliance monitoring and/or metering operations.
B. Nondomestic/industrial waste being discharged into the sewer system shall be subject to
periodic sampling and inspection by the Borough or its agent to be used as a basis for
determining additional charges due to excessive concentrations for BOD5, total suspended
303:36 07 - 01 - 2011
§ 303-73 SEWERS AND SEW AGE DISPOSAL § 303-74
solids and/or ammonia nitrogen and substances prohibited in Article IV of this chapter.
Such sampling and inspection shall be the basis for computing strong waste surcharges in
accordance with this section.
C. All sampling shall be of a representative manner and in accordance with 40 CFR 403.12.
The collection and analysis of samples obtained shall be made in accordance with EPA
methodology and procedures, including 40 CFR, Part 136, as amended.
D. Sampling frequency. Sampling of wastewater for the purpose of compliance
determinations will be done at such intervals as the Borough may designate. It is the
intention of the Borough to conduct compliance sampling or to cause such sampling to
be conducted for all nondomestic waste users at least once in every calendar year.
§ 303-74. Measurement of volume.
A. Whenever a person purchasing his entire water supply from a private or public water
supply discharges only nondomestic/industrial waste into the sewer system, the volume
of water purchased shall be used as a measure of the quantity of nondomestic/industrial
waste discharged.
B. Whenever a person purchasing his entire water supply from a private or public source
discharges combined domestic waste and nondomestic waste/industrial waste into the
sewer system, the total volume of water purchased shall be used to determine that
person's sewer charge and/or his strong waste surcharge .
C. Whenever a person purchasing his entire water supply from a private or public supply
and discharging nondomestic/industrial waste into the sewer system also discharges
unpolluted cooling water to either a storm sewer or other outlet, an allowance for the
amount of water so discharged shall be made in computing the sewer charge. The person
discharging cooling water shall, at his own expense, install a meter(s), as required, to
indicate accurately the amount of water claimed as a credit.
D. Whenever a person using a private water supply discharges nondomestic/industrial waste
into the sewer system, the charges for such discharge shall be in accordance with Articles
VIII, IX and X of this part. Such person, however, shall install, at his expense, a suitable
meter(s) to measure the total volume of water used or shall install, at his expense, a
meter on the sewer line leaving the plant so as to measure the entire flow of waste
discharged into the sewer system. No meter for measurement either of water or sewage
shall be installed until a plan for such installation is approved by the Borough. All meters
or other measuring devices installed or required to be used under the provisions of this
article shall be tested, inspected or repaired as required by the Borough. The owner of
the property upon which such measuring device is installed shall be responsible for its
maintenance and safekeeping, and all repairs thereto shall be made at the property
owner's expense.
E. The Borough shall be responsible for reading of water and/or sewage meters when
installed in industrial establishments within its jurisdiction. All meters shall be accessible
to the Borough or its agent at all times.
303:37 07 - 01 - 2011
§ 303-75 BIRDSBORO CODE § 303-79
§ 303-75. Adjustments.
The computation of such sewer rentals, including surcharges, shall be subject to all
adjustments provided for in this article.
ARTICLE X
Determination of Charges for Industrial Waste.
§ 303-76. Charges imposed for industrial waste.
There shall be additional sewer service charges for industrial users of the sewer system.
§ 303-77. Industrial waste surcharge.
Industrial waste surcharges shall be calculated in accordance with the methods set forth under
strong waste surcharges in Article IX of this part.
§ 303-78. Industrial cost recovery payments.
A. Industrial cost recovery charges are hereby imposed upon and shall be collected from the
owner of each industrial user which shall be connected to the treatment works for use of
the treatment works and which industrial users discharge wastewater other than domestic
sewage. Said charges shall commence and shall be effective as of the enactment date of
this chapter.
B. In order to determine the industrial cost recovery charge, the following formula shall be
used:
ICRQ = 0.137 Qi [1,034.54 + (4.906 BOD1) + (1.73 SS1)]
Where:
ICRQ = the quarterly industrial cost recovery charge expressed in dollars
Q1 = the total quarterly wastewater discharge expressed in million gallons
BOD1 and SS1 = the respective concentrations of BODs and suspended solids of the
wastewater discharged expressed in mg/l.
§ 303-79. Methods of payment of extra charges by industrial users.
A. The industrial cost recovery charge and the industrial waste surcharge shall be payable
quarterly. The Borough shall cause the water meter of each industrial user where the
wastewater flow determination is based upon metered water consumption, and the
wastewater meter where the wastewater flow determination is based upon wastewater
flow measurement, to be read on a quarterly basis and shall cause industrial cost
303:38 07 - 01 - 2011
§ 303-79 SEWERS AND SEW AGE DISPOSAL § 303-83
recovery bills and industrial waste surcharge bills to be mailed forthwith following each
reading.
B. The Borough shall cause periodic sampling of the wastewater discharged by each
industrial user in accordance with § 303-54 of this chapter.
C. The analysis of the sample shall be the basis for computing industrial cost recovery
charges and industrial waste surcharges.
D. Bills for industrial cost recovery and industrial waste surcharge shall be mailed to the
owner's address specified on the industrial waste discharge permit. Failure to receive a
bill as a result of incorrect address, or otherwise, shall not excuse nonpayment of charges
or extend the time for payment.
E. If any quarterly industrial cost recovery or industrial waste surcharge payment is not
made within 30 days after the date of the bill, a ten-percent penalty shall be added
thereto, and if the installment plus penalty is not paid within 60 days after the date of the
bill, the aggregate amount thereof shall bear interest from the penalty date at the rate of
112% per month or fraction thereof. Any unpaid bills (together with penalties and interest
thereon to the extent permitted by law) shall be a lien on the property served, which may
be collected by action in assumpsit, by distress or by a lien filed in the nature of a
municipal claim, as provided by law.
§ 303-80. New industrial users .
A new industrial user is one which connects to the treatment works after the effective date of
this chapter. Industrial cost recovery payments by a new industrial user shall begin on the date
treatment works use is initiated and shall continue for the unexpired portion of the industrial
cost recovery period or until the industrial user ceases use of this facility, whichever occurs
first. The industrial cost recovery period shall begin with the enactment date of this chapter
and continue for a period of 20 years. Industrial waste surcharge payments by a new industrial
user shall begin on the date treatment works use is initiated and continue indefinitely.
§ 303-81. Discontinuance of use.
If an industrial user discontinues use of the treatment works, its payment for industrial cost
recovery and for industrial waste surcharges will cease.
§ 303-82. Lump sum industrial cost recovery payment.
An industrial user may fulfill its industrial cost recovery obligation by making a lump sum
payment for its entire share of the cost of the construction of the treatment works. Such a
payment plan will be arranged upon request by an industrial user.
§ 303-83. Administrative appeal procedure.
Industrial users may appeal the reasonableness of the allocations and industrial cost recovery
or industrial waste surcharge assessments imposed upon them. Industrial users making such an
303:39 07 - 01 - 2011
§ 303-83 BIRDSBORO CODE § 303-85
appeal shall so notify the Borough, in writing. A hearing board will be appointed and an
administrative hearing will then be conducted. The industrial user will be given the
opportunity to present testimony before the hearing board supporting its appeal. The hearing
board shall consist of three members of the Authority and two members of Borough Council
to be selected by vote of the Authority.
§ 303-84. Additional surcharges.
The formula specified in § 303-77 of this article is to determine additional charges or
surcharges for the treatment of industrial waste. It is, however, recognized by the Borough
that the discharge of any waste or other material which contain any one or more of the
prohibited or limited substances listed in §§ 303-36 and 303-38 of this chapter may result in
extraordinary labor, maintenance and/or treatment expenses to the Borough. Hence, it shall be
the policy of the Borough, in the event of the discharge of any industrial waste or other matter
or containing any one of the prohibited substances listed in §§ 303-36 and 303-38 of this
chapter, to bill the owner of the property from which the said discharge is made an additional
surcharge of $100. Each day that the said discharge is made may result in a separate $100
additional surcharge. This one-hundred-dollar charge shall be in addition to the normal sewer
rental and/or any extra industrial waste charges incurred under this section.
ARTICLE XI
Time and Method of Payment.
§ 303-85. Payment terms established.
A. The tapping fee, connection fee and permit and inspection fees imposed by §§ 303-59,
303-60 and 303-61 of this part shall be payable upon application for a permit to make the
connection. The sewer rents imposed by Article VIII shall be payable quarterly.
B. All bills with respect to billing units shall be rendered each calendar quarter on January
1, April 1, July 1 and October 1 of each year for service during the preceding quarter
annum.
C. All bills shall be due and payable without penalty one day after mailing or delivery by or
in behalf of the Borough to the person responsible for payment thereof. If any quarterly
installment of sewer rent is not paid within 30 days after the date of the bill, a
ten-percent penalty shall be added thereto, and if the installment plus penalty is not paid
within 60 days after the date of the bill, the aggregate amount thereof shall bear interest
from the penalty date at the rate of 112% per month or fraction thereof. Payments mailed
and postmarked on or before such 30th day shall be deemed to be payments within the
period allowed for payment without penalty. If such 30th day shall be a legal holiday or
a Sunday, payments made on or mailed and postmarked on the next succeeding business
day not a legal holiday shall be deemed to be payments within the period allowed for
payment without penalty.
D. Any unpaid sewer rent (together with penalties and interest thereon to the extent
permitted by law) shall be a lien on the property served, which may be collected by
action in assumpsit, by distress or by a lien filed in the nature of a municipal claim, as
303:40 07 - 01 - 2011
§ 303-85 SEWERS AND SEW AGE DISPOSAL § 303-88
provided by law. In addition, the Borough may require any water utility to shut off the
water supply to any property with respect to which the sewer rent imposed hereby is
unpaid until all such rents, together with interest and penalties as aforesaid, are paid.
E. Whenever service to any billing unit shall begin after the first day or shall terminate
before the last day of any calendar quarter, the sewer rental or charge for such period
shall be prorated equitably for that portion of the calendar quarter during which service
was provided by the Borough.
F. Every owner of improved property which is connected to the sewer system initially shall
provide the Borough with and thereafter shall keep the Borough advised of his correct
address. Failure of any person to receive quarterly bills for sewer rentals or charges shall
not be considered an excuse for nonpayment nor shall such failure result in an extension
of the period of time during which such bill shall be payable without penalty.
§ 303-86. Liens for sewer rentals and charges; filing and collection of liens.
The sewer rentals or charges hereby imposed shall be a lien on the improved property
connected to and served by the sewer system from the date such sewer rental or charge
becomes due and payable under provisions of this article. All sewer rentals or charges hereby
imposed which shall not be paid after 30 days, as provided in § 303-85C of this article, shall
be entered as a lien against the improved property so connected to and served by the sewer
system, which lien shall be filed in the office of the Prothonotary of Berks County,
Pennsylvania, in the manner provided by law for the filing of municipal claims. All delinquent
bills shall be collected by the Borough in any manner permitted and authorized by law.
§ 303-87. Additions to and changes of sewer rentals and charges; adoption of additional
rules and regulations.
A. The Borough reserves the right to adopt and promulgate and, from time to time, the
Borough may adopt and promulgate, as it shall deem necessary, additional classifications
and sewer rentals or charges therefor, or modifications of the schedule of sewer rentals or
charges as set forth in this part, which additional classifications and sewer rentals or
charges or modifications, as the case may be, shall be, shall become and shall be
construed as a part of this part.
B. The Borough reserves the right to adopt and promulgate and, from time to time, the
Borough may adopt and promulgate such additional rules and regulations as it shall deem
necessary and proper for the use and operation of the sewer system, which regulations
shall be, shall become and shall be construed as a part of this part.
§ 303-88. Violations and penalties.
Any person, firm or corporation who shall violate any of the provisions of this part or the
rules, regulations or standards promulgated thereunder or resist or interfere with any officer,
agent or employee of the Borough, in accordance with the provisions of this part, in the
performance of his duties shall, upon conviction thereof, be sentenced to pay a fine of not less
than $50 nor more than $1,000 plus costs and, in default of payment of said fine and costs, to
303:41 07 - 01 - 2011
§ 303-88 BIRDSBORO CODE § 303-88
a term of imprisonment not to exceed 30 days. Each day that a violation of this part continues
shall constitute a separate offense.

ARTICLE I
Storage of Refuse
[Adopted 5-8-1989 by Ord. No. 324]
§ 318-1. Establishing public nuisance.
The Council of the Borough of Birdsboro has determined that the storage or accumulation of
refuse or garbage on or in vehicles parked within the Borough constitutes a public nuisance
except for a period of time not exceeding one hour.
§ 318-2. Prohibiting storage of refuse.
The storage or accumulation of refuse or garbage on or in vehicles parked within the Borough
for a period of time exceeding one hour is prohibited.
318:1 07 - 01 - 2011
§ 318-3 BIRDSBORO CODE § 318-5
§ 318-3. Violations and penalties. 1
Any person, firm or corporation who shall violate any provision of this article shall, upon
conviction thereof, be sentenced to pay a fine of not more than $1,000 plus costs and, in
default of payment of said fine and costs, to a term of imprisonment not to exceed 30 days.
Each day that a violation of this article continues shall constitute a separate offense.
§ 318-4. Purpose.
ARTICLE II
Solid Waste Collection; Recycling
[Adopted 12-9-2002 by Ord. No. 374]
Effective January 1, 2003, the Borough of Birdsboro, as required by the "Municipal Waste
Planning, Recycling and Waste Reduction Act," Act 101 of 1988,2 has placed into effect this
article for the express intent of governing residential, commercial, institutional and municipal
establishment recycling, and recycling at community activities. Additionally, the Borough of
Birdsboro has placed into effect this article for the express intent of governing residential,
commercial, institutional and municipal establishment of solid waste disposal.
§ 318-5. Definitions.
The following terms have the meanings set forth below, unless a different meaning is plainly
required by the context:
ALUMINUM CANS - Empty, nonaerosol all aluminum beverage and food cans.
BIMET AL CONTAINERS - Empty beverage cans consisting of aluminum, tin and steel.
BULKY RUBBISH - Discarded furniture and large household appliance, such as
refrigerators, stoves, washing machines, dryers, bathtubs, sinks, commodes, etc.
COMMERCIAL ESTABLISHMENTS - Those properties used primarily for the
commercial or industrial purpose, excluding those multiple dwelling residential buildings
containing more than four dwelling units.
COMMUNITY ACTIVITIES - Church, school, c1v1c service group, municipal functions
and all other such functions.
CONTRACTOR - The person with whom the Borough of Birdsboro shall enter into a
contract for the municipal waste collection and recycling collection service, including said
contractor's employees.
CORRUGATED PAPER - Structural paper materials with an inner core shaped in rigid
parallel furrows and ridges.

DISPOSAL - The storage, collection, disposal or handling of refuse.
DROPOFF SITES - Those specified locations where recyclable materials may be taken by

DWELLINGSA.
DWELLING UNIT- Any structure built and used for the habitation of a family.

operated by or on behalf of a municipality. The term shall not include any program for

MUNICIPALITY - The Borough of Birdsboro, Berks County, Pennsylvania.

NEWSPAPER - Paper of the type commonly referred to as "newsprint," having printed

shrubbery and tree trimmings. The term does not include grass clippings.

§ 318-6 SOLID WASTE § 318-7
§ 318-6. Word usage.
Any masculine pronoun includes the feminine and any singular reference means the plural,
wherever appropriate.
§ 318-7. Solid waste collection program.
A. The Borough of Birdsboro hereby establishes a mandatory program for the separation,
storage and disposal of municipal solid waste by persons residing within the Borough of
Birdsboro. After the solid waste collection service has been instituted within the Borough
of Birdsboro, the program will be mandatory. Occupants shall be responsible for the
separation of recyclable materials from solid waste and their preparation and placement
at curbside.
B. Residential dwellings.
(1) There is hereby established a municipal solid waste program for the separation,
storage and disposal of solid waste by persons residing in single-family dwellings,
two-family dwellings or multifamily dwellings having up to and including four
dwelling units per structure.
(2) The Borough of Birdsboro shall be responsible for scheduling a day, at least once a
week, for the collection of solid waste. The Borough Council shall establish and
modify this schedule and communicate it to the residents of the Borough and to
make regulations pursuant to this article .
(3) Municipal solid waste from residential dwellings shall be placed at the curb or
other designated place, separate from recycling, for collection, at such times, dates
and places, and in such manner as may be established by the Regulation to the
Solid Waste Management and Recycling Ordinance. Failure to separate solid waste
from recyclables shall be a violation of this article.
(4) Persons shall be required to store municipal solid waste until they or the Borough
or its agents collects them. Nothing in these regulations shall be deemed to impair
the ownership of solid waste by the person who generated them unless and until
such waste are placed at curbside or similar locations and collected by the Borough
of Birdsboro or its agent(s).
(5) All municipal solid waste shall be placed in durable, rust-resistant, watertight
containers which are provided by the owner, tenant or occupant.
(6) No person shall place, throw or deposit any refuse originating outside the Borough
of Birdsboro in any container or otherwise so as to cause or attempt to cause such
refuse to be collected at the expense of the Borough as part of the municipal
collection, nor shall any person entitled to such collection allow or consent to the
throwing, placing or depositing of such refuse for such purpose.
C. Commercial, municipal and institutional establishments and community activities.
(1) Commercial, municipal and institutional establishments shall separate and store,
until collection, all municipal solid waste. These establishments must arrange for
318:5 07 - 01 - 2011
§ 318-7 BIRDSBORO CODE § 318-7
the transfer of the materials, at least once a week, to a collector licensed for the
purpose of collecting municipal solid waste by the Borough of Birdsboro.
(2) At community activities, municipal solid waste shall be collected and stored in the
containers provided by the Borough of Birdsboro for the purpose of collection.
Sponsors or coordinators of community activities shall ensure that waste is
collected and stored for pick up by the Borough of Birdsboro.
D. Multifamily housing properties.
(l) The owner, landlord or agent of an owner or landlord of a multifamily housing
property of more than four units shall be responsible for providing municipal solid
waste disposal at the housing units. The Borough of Birdsboro will make solid
waste collection available at multifamily housing property of more than four units
upon the owner's notification to the Borough of Birdsboro. The owner, landlord or
agent of an owner or landlord of a multifamily housing property of more than four
units shall notify the Borough of Birdsboro of the intent to participate in the
Borough's municipal waste collection program. If the owner, landlord or agent of
an owner or landlord of a multifamily housing property of more than four units
does not participate in the Borough of Birdsboro municipal waste collection
program, they will be responsible for establishing a collection program at the
property. The owner, landlord or agent of an owner or landlord of a multifamily
housing property of more than four units shall be responsible for scheduling a day,
at least twice a week, for the collection of recyclable materials.
(2) The owner, landlord or agent of an owner or landlord of a multifamily housing
property of more than four units shall be responsible for providing collection
containers or ensuring that the occupant(s) or tenant(s) provide collection
containers.
E. Licensing of solid waste collector.
(1) Municipal solid waste collectors who provide a collection program for multifamily
properties of more than four units, commercial, municipal and institutional
establishments shall be licensed with the Borough of Birdsboro.
(2) Recycling collectors shall complete the Borough of Birdsboro recycling collection
application and remit a fee, as established by the Regulation to the Solid Waste
Management and Recycling Ordinance, to the Borough by February l of each year.
(3) Any municipal solid waste collector who collects municipal solid waste in the
Borough of Birdsboro who does not obtain a license to do so from the Borough
shall, upon conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine, as established by the
Regulation to the Solid Waste Management and Recycling Ordinance, and costs of
such proceedings or, upon default of payment of such fines and costs, by
imprisonment in the county jail for a term of not more than 30 days. The
continuation of such violation for each successive day shall constitute a separate
offense, and the person or persons allowing or permitting the continuation of the
violation may be punished as provided above for each separate offense.
318:6 07 - 01 - 2011
§ 318-7 SOLID WASTE § 318-8
F. Time of placement for collection. Refuse shall not be placed for collection prior to 4:00
p.m. on the day prior to the scheduled collection. Refuse containers shall be promptly
removed after said collection.
§ 318-8. Recycling program.
A. Those recyclable materials separated under the provisions of this article shall not be
considered municipal waste and shall not be subject to provisions of this article which
requires disposal of municipal waste at designated facilities. This exemption applies to
recyclable materials collected by the Borough of Birdsboro or its agents and delivered to
an intermediate processing facility for purposes of materials recovery. Likewise, the
collector of recycling materials shall be exempt from all provisions of those ordinances
which require disposal of municipal waste by licensed haulers. Recyclables separated,
stored, collected or delivered in any manner other than the approved methods listed in
this article, which shall be adopted by the Borough of Birdsboro, from time to time, shall
be considered municipal waste and be subject to the provisions of the appropriate
ordinance.
B. The Borough of Birdsboro hereby establishes a mandatory program for the separation of
recyclable materials from municipal solid waste by persons residing within the Borough
of Birdsboro. After curbside service has been instituted within the Borough of Birdsboro,
the recycling program will be mandatory. Occupants shall be responsible for the
separation of recyclable materials from solid waste and their preparation and placement
at curbside. Certain recyclable materials may also be delivered to an established dropoff
site.
C. Residential dwellings.
(1) There is hereby established a municipal recycling program for the mandatory
separation of recyclable materials from solid waste by persons residing in
single-family dwellings, two-family dwellings or multifamily dwellings having up
to and including four dwelling units per structure.
(2) The Borough of Birdsboro shall be responsible for scheduling a day, at least once a
month, for the collection of recyclable material. The Borough Council shall
establish and modify this schedule and delegate the responsibility for
communicating it to the residents of the Borough, and to make regulations
pursuant to this article, to the Recycling Coordinator.
(3) Recyclable materials from residential dwellings shall be placed at the curb or other
designated place, separate from municipal waste for collection or taken to dropoff
sites, at such times, dates and places, and in such manner as may be established by
the Regulation to the Solid Waste Management and Recycling Ordinance.
Separated recyclables shall not be placed in the same containers or otherwise
mixed with other forms of nonrecyclable municipal waste for collection, removal
or disposal. Failure to separate recyclables from nonrecyclables shall be a violation
of this article.
318:7 07 - 01 - 2011
§ 318-8 BIRDSBORO CODE § 318-8
(4) The Borough Council shall establish and modify the materials to be recycled by
the Regulation to the Solid Waste Management and Recycling Ordinance.
(5) Persons shall be required to store recyclables until they recycle them or until the
Borough or its agents collects them. Nothing in these regulations shall be deemed
to impair the ownership of separated materials by the person who generated them
unless and until such materials are placed at curbside or similar locations for the
collection by the Borough of Birdsboro or its agent(s).
(6) The recyclable materials shall be placed in containers which will be provided by
the Borough of Birdsboro. Said containers shall be and remain the property of the
Borough of Birdsboro. The Borough may require a refundable deposit, established
by the Regulation to the Solid Waste Management and Recycling Ordinance, to
ensure that the containers remain the property of the Borough of Birdsboro. Any
misuse or destruction of said containers shall subject the person responsible to
penalty as hereafter set forth. Should the containers become lost or unusable, they
must be replaced by notifying the Recycling Coordinator. The Borough is
authorized to charge a replacement fee in accordance with rules and regulations of
the Borough of Birdsboro.
D. Commercial, municipal and institutional establishments and community activities.
(1) Commercial, municipal and institutional establishments shall separate and store,
until collection, high-grade office paper, corrugated paper, aluminum and any other
material that are established by the Regulation to the Solid Waste Management and
Recycling Ordinance. These establishments must arrange for the transfer of the
materials at least once a month to a recycling system by a collector licensed for the
purpose of collecting source-separated recyclable materials by the Borough of
Birdsboro.
(2) The owner of each commercial, municipal and institutional establishment shall
provide a quarterly report to the Borough of Birdsboro as evidence of each such
arrangement. The report shall document the type and total weight of material
recycled at the establishment. Weight slips/invoices must also be submitted with
the quarterly report, documenting the total weight of the material recycled.
(3) At community activities, the following materials shall be separated and stored until
collection: high-grade office paper, corrugated paper, aluminum and any other
material that are established by the Regulation to the Solid Waste Management and
Recycling Ordinance. Sponsors or coordinators of community activities shall
ensure that these materials are collected, stored and delivered for recycling to a
location designated by the Borough of Birdsboro.
(4) Commercial, municipal and institutional establishments and sponsors or
coordinators of community activities shall not be liable for the noncompliance of
their tenants where a portion of the building is leased to tenant(s) and/or for the
noncompliance by the general public where there is public access to the building
or grounds or in other public places.
E. Multifamily housing properties.
318:8 07 - 01 - 2011
§ 318-8 SOLID WASTE § 318-8
(1) The owner, landlord or agent of an owner or landlord of a multifamily housing
property of more than four units shall make recycling collection available at the
housing units. The Borough of Birdsboro will make curbside collection available at
multifamily housing properties of more than four units upon the owner's
notification to the Borough Recycling Coordinator. The owner, landlord or agent
of an owner or landlord of a multifamily housing property of more than four units
shall notify the Borough of Birdsboro of the intent to participate in the Borough's
recycling program. If the owner, landlord or agent of an owner or landlord of a
multifamily housing property of more than four units does not participate in the
Borough of Birdsboro curbside recycling program, they will be responsible for
establishing a collection system of recyclables at the property. The owner, landlord
or agent of an owner or landlord of a multifamily housing property of more than
four units shall be responsible for scheduling a day, at least once a month, for the
collection of recyclable materials.
(2) The Borough Council shall establish and modify the materials to be recycled by
the Regulation to the Solid Waste Management and Recycling Ordinance.
(3) The owner, landlord or agent of an owner or landlord of a multifamily housing
property of more than four units shall notify the Borough of Birdsboro if they
require recycling containers. The Borough of Birdsboro shall make the Borough's
recycling containers available to the multifamily housing owner, landlord or agent
of an owner or landlord available at the same refundable deposit, established by
the Regulation to the Solid Waste Management and Recycling Ordinance. If the
owner, landlord or agent of an owner or landlord of a multifamily housing property
of more than four units does not want the Borough's recycling containers, the
owner, landlord or agent for the owner or landlord shall then provide suitable
containers to the tenants of the multifamily housing property.
(4) If the owner, landlord or agent of an owner or landlord of a multifamily housing
property of more than four units does not participate in the Borough's recycling
program, then the same must arrange for the collection of the recyclable material
by a recycling collector licensed in the Borough of Birdsboro.
(5) The owner, landlord or agent of an owner or landlord of a multifamily housing
property of more than four units, who does not participate in the Borough of
Birdsboro's recycling program, shall provide a quarterly report, reportable as listed
in Subsection F(2), to the Borough of Birdsboro as evidence of each such
arrangement. The report shall document the type and total weight of material
recycled at the establishment. Weight slips/invoices must also be submitted with
the quarterly report, documenting the total weight of the material recycled.
F. Licensing of recycling collector.
(1) Recycling collectors who provide a recycling collection program for multifamily
properties of more than four units, commercial, municipal and institutional
establishments shall be licensed with the Borough of Birdsboro.
(2) Recycling collectors shall complete the Borough of Birdsboro recycling collection
application and remit a fee, as established by the Regulation to the Solid Waste
318:9 07 - 01 - 2011
§ 318-8 BIRDSBORO CODE § 318-8
Management and Recycling Ordinance, to the Borough by February 1 of each year.
Every recycling collector shall furnish to the Borough of Birdsboro a quarterly
recycling report indicating the total weight of the recyclables collected, the type of
recyclables collected and a list of customers whose sum total equal the tonnage
claimed on the quarterly recycling report. The quarterly recycling reports are due
to the Borough of Birdsboro on the following dates:
(a) January 1 to March 31, submit by April 15.
(b) April 1 to June 30, submit by July 15.
(c) July 1 to September 30, submit by October 15.
(d) October 1 to December 31, submit by January 15.
(3) Nonprofit organizations that provide recycling collection for multifamily properties
of more than four units, commercial, municipal and institutional establishments are
exempt from the license fee, but shall be required to submit the recycling
collection license application and file the required quarterly reports.
G. Violations and penalties. Any recycling collector (except nonprofit organizations) who
collects recyclables in the Borough of Birdsboro and does not obtain a license to do so
from the Borough, or any recycling collector who fails to submit the quarterly recycling
reports to the Borough, shall, upon conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine, as
established by the Regulation to the Solid Waste Management and Recycling Ordinance,
and costs of such proceedings or, upon default of payment of such fine and costs, by
imprisonment in the county jail for a term of not more than 30 days. The continuation of
such violation for each successive day shall constitute a separate offense, and the person
or persons allowing or permitting the continuation of the violation may be punished as
provided above for each separate offense.
H. Lead acid batteries. No person may place a used lead acid battery in mixed municipal
solid waste, discard or otherwise dispose of a lead acid battery except by delivery to an
automobile battery retail or wholesale location, to a secondary lead smelter permitted by
the Environmental Protection Agency or to a collection or recycling facility authorized
under the laws of the Commonwealth.
I. Separation and disposal of leaves and yard waste. [Amended 5-10-2004 by Ord. No.
384]
(1) All persons who reside in residential dwellings and all persons who are responsible
for administration of multifamily housing properties, commercial, municipal and
institutional establishments, who gather leaves, shall source separate all leaves
from other waste and place them for collection at the times and in the manner
prescribed by the Borough of Birdsboro. Leaves are not to be incorporated into the
regular municipal waste stream. Nothing herein shall require any person to gather
leaves or prevent any person from utilizing leaves for compost, mulch or other
agricultural, horticultural, silvicultural, gardening or landscaping purposes.
(2) All persons who reside in residential dwellings and all persons who are responsible

institutional establishments, who gather yard waste, shall source separate all such
yard waste from other waste and dispose of said materials at the times and in the
manner prescribed by the Borough of Birdsboro. Yard waste is not to be
incorporated into the regular municipal waste stream. Nothing herein shall require

J. Ownership and unauthorized collection.
(1) From the time of placement at the curb or designated dropoff site(s), the recyclable
materials as designated by the Borough of Birdsboro to be recycled pursuant to the
provisions of this article and the regulations issued hereunder, such material shall
become and be the property of the Borough of Birdsboro. It shall be a violation of
the terms of this article for any person, other than the licensed recycling collector
to collect, pick up or caused to be collected or picked up any such materials.
(2) If any person, firm, corporation or other entity removes or causes to be collected or
removed any recyclable materials as defined by the Borough in Subsection C(4) of
this section, in violation of the provisions of this article, such person, firm,
corporation, or other entity shall, upon conviction thereof, be sentenced to pay a
fine of not more than $1,000 plus costs and, in default of payment of said fine and
costs, to a term of imprisonment not to exceed 30 days.3
(3) Each day a violation shall constitute a separate and distinct offense and shall be
subject to separate summary proceedings before a Magisterial District Judge and
subject to the penalty imposed by this section for each and every day such
violation shall continue.
K. Nonparticipation.
(1) Upon the discovery of any violation under the terms of this section, the Borough
shall, through its authorized agent(s), give notice to the owner or occupant of a
violation hereunder, either by person delivery to such owner or occupant, by the
United States Mail directed to the last known address of such person or persons, as
shown in the real estate registry records of the Borough, or by leaving the same on
the premises where the violation occurs.
(2) Nothing contained in this section shall affect, in any way, the provisions of this
article regarding separate offenses for every day any violation occurs.

L. Fines for nonparticipation or nonpayment. On neglect or refusal of the occupant of any
dwelling serviced by curbside recycling collection, a multifamily housing program, or a
commercial, municipal, institutional or community activity program to separate
recyclable materials from municipal solid waste and place them at curbside or sites
established by the Borough, in the Regulation to the Solid Waste Management and
Recycling Ordinance, or to pay the penalty or penalties specified in Subsection J(2), that
person shall, upon conviction of such default, neglect or refusal, pay a fine, as
established by the Regulation to the Solid Waste Management and Recycling Ordinance,
together with the costs of prosecution, to be collected as now provided by law. Each
violation shall constitute a separate offense.
M. Pilfering. If any person is responsible for pilfering of collection containers issued to a
residence slated for either curbside collection or any other phase of the recycling
collection program, such person shall, upon conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine,
as established by the Regulation to the Solid Waste Management and Recycling
Ordinance, and costs of such proceedings or, upon default of payment of such fine and
costs, by imprisonment in the county jail for a term of not more than 30 days. The
continuation of such violation for each successive day shall constitute a separate offense,
and the person or persons allowing or permitting the continuation of the violation may be
punished as provided above for each separate offense. The affected resident will be
responsible for replacing any missing container through purchase from the Borough of
Birdsboro.
N. Delivery of recyclable materials.
(1) All recyclable materials must be delivered by the licensed collector to sites for
recycling.
(2) It shall be a violation of this article for the licensed collector of recyclable
materials to deliver such materials to a landfill or incinerator for the purpose of
disposal, unless the markets for such materials no longer exist.

or the Regulation to the Solid Waste Management and Recycling Ordinance, which shall be
